docs.text:

docs.title: DRUIDS Markdown Linter
docs.text: A comprehensive Markdown linting system for DRUIDS documentation that ensures MkDocs Material compatibility and enforces security classification standards.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The DRUIDS Markdown Linter combines: - markdownlint-cli2 for general Markdown syntax validation - Custom Python linter for DRUIDS-specific requirements - JavaScript custom rules for enhanced validation - Pre-commit integration for automatic checking

docs.title: Quick Setup
docs.text:
From any DRUIDS vault or project directory:

# Install the linter configuration
bash /path/to/repos/shared/scripts/bash/install-markdown-linter.sh

# Install dependencies
npm install -g markdownlint-cli2
pip install pre-commit pyyaml python-frontmatter

# Set up pre-commit hooks
pre-commit install

docs.title: Manual Setup
docs.text:
1. Copy configuration files: 

    cp repos/shared/configs/markdownlint/.markdownlint.yml .
cp repos/shared/configs/markdownlint/.markdownlint-cli2.jsonc .

  2. Add to .pre-commit-config.yaml (see example in root directory)

docs.title: DRUIDS-Specific Validation
docs.text:
1. Security Classification
  2. Validates security field (L0, L1, L2)
  3. Ensures documents are in correct vault directories
  4. Checks document ID security suffix matches metadata

  5. CRITICAL: Never processes L2/cadre content

  6. Required Frontmatter

  7. title: Document title
  8. type: Document type (guide, reference, etc.)
  9. security: Security classification (L0/L1/L2)

  10. document_id: Unique identifier in format ROLE-TYPE-YYYY-SEQUENCE-SECURITY

  11. Document ID Format

  12. Pattern: ^[A-Z]{2,5}-[A-Z]{2,5}-\d{4}-\d+[A-Z]?-L[0-2]$
  13. Example: DEV-GUIDE-2024-001-L0

docs.title: MkDocs Material Compatibility
docs.text:
1. Admonitions
  2. Validates proper indentation (4 spaces)
  3. Supports all Material admonition types

  4. Checks both !!! and ??? formats

  5. Content Tabs

  6. Ensures proper === syntax

  7. Validates tab content indentation

  8. Internal Links

  9. Removes .md extensions (MkDocs doesn't need them)
  10. Enforces relative paths

  11. Validates link targets

  12. Code Blocks

  13. Requires language specification
  14. Validates fence style (backticks)
  15. Checks for proper spacing

docs.title: Command Line
docs.text:
# Lint all markdown files
markdownlint-cli2 "**/*.md"

# Lint with DRUIDS-specific checks
python repos/shared/scripts/python/markdown-linter.py

# Lint specific file
python repos/shared/scripts/python/markdown-linter.py file.md

# Copy config files to current directory
python repos/shared/scripts/python/markdown-linter.py --copy-config

docs.title: Pre-commit Hook
docs.text:
Once installed, the linter runs automatically on git commit:

git add document.md
git commit -m "Add new document"
# Linter runs automatically

To run manually: 

pre-commit run --all-files

docs.title: .markdownlint.yml
docs.text: Main configuration file with rule settings: - Heading styles (ATX only) - List formatting (2-space indent) - Code block requirements - Allowed HTML elements for MkDocs

docs.title: .markdownlint-cli2.jsonc
docs.text: Extended configuration: - Custom rule locations - File globs and ignores - Frontmatter handling - Markdown-it plugins for MkDocs extensions

docs.title: Custom Rules
docs.text:
Located in repos/shared/scripts/js/markdownlint-rules/:

  1. druids-frontmatter.js - Validates required frontmatter fields
  2. druids-security.js - Enforces security classification rules
  3. mkdocs-links.js - Checks internal link formatting

docs.title: Common Errors
docs.text:
Missing required frontmatter field: security
Fix: Add security: L0 (or L1/L2) to frontmatter

Security mismatch: L0 required for public vault, got L1
Fix: Move file to correct vault or update security classification

Invalid document_id format: invalid-id
Fix: Use format like DEV-GUIDE-2024-001-L0

Remove .md extension from internal link: ../other.md
Fix: Change to ../other (MkDocs adds extensions automatically)

Code block without language specification (line 42)
Fix: Add language after opening fence: ```python

docs.title: Common Warnings
docs.text:
Admonition content must be indented with 4 spaces
Fix: Indent content under !!! or ??? directives

Tab content must be indented with 4 spaces
Fix: Indent content under === tab markers

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
Run the test suite:

python -m pytest tests/test_markdown_linter.py -v

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
• Linting is fast (<5 seconds for hundreds of files)
  • Pre-commit hook adds minimal overhead
  • Suitable for continuous integration

docs.title: Security Note
docs.text: The linter is configured to completely ignore the /vault/cadre/ directory. This is a critical security feature - L2 content must never be processed by automated tools or AI systems.

docs.title: Quick Start: 15 Minutes to Revolutionary Organization
docs.text: Time Investment: 15 minutes Outcome: Create your first secure meeting minutes and understand why DRUIDS changes everything

docs.title: 🎯 What DRUIDS Solves (30 seconds)
docs.text:
Your revolutionary organization probably faces these problems:

  • One person has all the passwords (and when they burn out, you're screwed)
  • Important decisions get lost in endless chat threads
  • Security is a joke (posting strategy docs in public channels)
  • New members take months to figure out how to contribute

DRUIDS fixes all of this with Git-based infrastructure designed for small revolutionary organizations.

docs.title: Step 1: Clone Your First Vault
docs.text:
# Create workspace
mkdir -p ~/druids-demo && cd ~/druids-demo

# Clone the public vault (you'll need access - ask in Discord)
git clone https://github.com/ks-sbc/vault-public.git

docs.title: Step 2: Open in Obsidian (3 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Download Obsidian (free, works offline)
  2. Open Obsidian → "Open folder as vault" → Select vault-public
  3. See those green borders? That's L0 (public) security - visual indicators prevent accidents

docs.title: Step 3: Create Your First Meeting Minutes (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl/Cmd + P → Type "QuickAdd" → Select "Meeting Minutes"
  2. Fill in the basics:
  3. Meeting type: "General"
  4. Committee: "Education"
  5. Security: "L0"
  6. Watch as it creates: INT-MIN-2025-181-L0 Education Committee General Meeting.md

What just happened?

  • Automatic document ID that's unique and sortable
  • Proper security classification
  • Template with agenda, attendees, decisions
  • Searchable, permanent record

docs.title: Step 4: Understand Security Tiers (2 minutes)
docs.text:
Look at the visual coding:

  • 🟢 Green (L0): Public info, educational materials
  • 🟡 Gold (L1): Member-only, internal planning
  • 🔴 Red (L2): Sensitive strategy, legal defense

This isn't paranoia - it's protection against real threats like raids or infiltration.

docs.title: Step 5: See the Power (3 minutes)
docs.text:
Try these commands in Obsidian:

  • Ctrl/Cmd + O → Search "decision" - Find every decision ever made
  • Click any [[WikiLink]] - Everything is connected
  • Look at Git history - See who changed what and why

Compare to your current system:

  • Can you find last month's decisions in 5 seconds?
  • Do new members know where anything is?
  • Could you survive if your main organizer disappeared tomorrow?

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text: The DRUIDS documentation should follow a problem → solution → proof → action flow that maximizes persuasion while maintaining easy access to technical references. The current structure is good but can be optimized for different user types and their decision-making processes.

docs.text:
Goal: Convince non-technical leaders that DRUIDS solves their real problems

Landing → Problem Recognition → Social Proof → Quick Win → Gradual Adoption

Optimal Flow: 1. Homepage: Start with painful problems (current structure is good!) 2. Why DRUIDS > Fundamental Problems: Deeper dive into pain points 3. Why DRUIDS > Before/After: Show transformation stories 4. Getting Started > Demo: Interactive proof it works 5. Quick Start: 15-minute win to build confidence 6. Getting Started > For Organizers: Non-technical guide

docs.title: Comments and Discussion Guide
docs.text: The DRUIDS wiki uses Giscus for comments, leveraging GitHub Discussions for a privacy-respecting, community-driven discussion system.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Giscus provides:

  • Privacy-Respecting: No tracking, ads, or cookies beyond GitHub authentication
  • GitHub Integration: Uses GitHub Discussions as the backend
  • Mandalorian Theme: Custom styling matching our tactical aesthetic
  • Security: Origin restrictions and GitHub's authentication

docs.title: How to Enable Comments
docs.text:
To enable comments on any documentation page, add the following to the page's frontmatter:

---
comments: true
---

Comments are disabled by default on all pages for security and focus.

docs.title: Posting Comments
docs.text:
1. Authentication: Click "Sign in with GitHub" to authenticate
  2. Write: Use the comment box with Markdown support
  3. Preview: Check your comment before posting
  4. Submit: Post your comment to the discussion

docs.title: Comment Features
docs.text:
• Markdown Support: Full GitHub-flavored Markdown
  • Code Blocks: Syntax highlighting for code snippets
  • Reactions: 👍 👎 😄 🎉 😕 ❤️ 🚀 👀
  • Replies: Thread discussions under comments
  • Editing: Edit your own comments after posting

docs.title: Community Standards
docs.text:
1. Be Respectful: Treat all members with respect
  2. Stay On Topic: Keep discussions relevant to the documentation
  3. Constructive Feedback: Provide helpful, actionable feedback
  4. No Spam: Avoid promotional or off-topic content

docs.title: Moderation Tools
docs.text:
Repository maintainers can:

  • Lock discussions to prevent new comments
  • Hide inappropriate comments
  • Delete spam or offensive content
  • Transfer discussions to more appropriate categories

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[DRUIDS Wiki] -->|embeds| B[Giscus Widget]
    B -->|authenticates| C[GitHub OAuth]
    B -->|stores in| D[GitHub Discussions]
    D -->|returns to| B
    B -->|displays in| A

docs.title: Security Features
docs.text:
1. Origin Restrictions: Only allowed domains can embed comments
{
  "origins": [
    "https://druids.kssocialistbookclub.com",
    "http://localhost:8000"
  ]
}
  1. Authentication: GitHub's OAuth ensures users are authenticated
  2. Content Security: GitHub's anti-spam and content policies apply

docs.title: Theme Integration
docs.text:
Comments automatically adapt to the site's theme:

  • Dark Mode: Mandalorian tactical theme
  • Light Mode: Currently uses the same theme (customizable)
  • Custom CSS: Located at /assets/stylesheets/giscus-druids.css

docs.title: For Contributors
docs.text:
1. Search First: Check if your question has been answered
  2. Be Specific: Provide context and examples
  3. Use Code Blocks: Format code properly for readability
  4. Link Issues: Reference related GitHub issues when relevant

docs.title: For Maintainers
docs.text:
1. Regular Review: Check discussions weekly
  2. Quick Response: Acknowledge questions within 48 hours
  3. Documentation Updates: Convert FAQs into documentation
  4. Community Building: Encourage helpful contributors

docs.title: Comments Not Appearing
docs.text:
1. Check Frontmatter: Ensure comments: true is set
  2. GitHub Login: Verify you're logged into GitHub
  3. Browser Extensions: Disable ad blockers temporarily
  4. Clear Cache: Try hard refresh (Ctrl+Shift+R)

docs.title: Styling Issues
docs.text:
1. Theme Conflicts: Check browser console for CSS errors
  2. Custom Themes: Ensure Giscus CSS is loaded after Material theme
  3. Mobile View: Comments are responsive but may stack vertically

docs.title: Repository Configuration
docs.text:
Ensure your GitHub repository has:

  1. Discussions Enabled: Settings → Features → Discussions
  2. Public Access: Comments require public repository
  3. Giscus App: Install from giscus.app

docs.title: Custom Categories
docs.text:
Create discussion categories in GitHub for:

  • Documentation Feedback
  • Feature Requests
  • Bug Reports
  • General Discussion

docs.title: Webhook Integration
docs.text:
For advanced workflows, configure GitHub webhooks to:

  • Notify maintainers of new comments
  • Sync comments to external systems
  • Generate comment analytics

docs.title: Data Storage
docs.text:
• All comments stored in GitHub's infrastructure
  • No additional tracking beyond GitHub's analytics
  • Users control their own data through GitHub

docs.title: GDPR Compliance
docs.text:
• No cookies set by Giscus
  • GitHub handles data processing agreements
  • Users can delete their own comments

docs.title: Future Enhancements
docs.text:
Planned improvements:

  1. L1/L2 Comment Sections: Separate discussions by security level
  2. Auto-Translation: Multi-language comment support
  3. AI Moderation: Automated spam detection
  4. Knowledge Base Integration: Convert discussions to documentation

For technical support with comments, please open an issue on GitHub.

docs.title: Democratic Centralism
docs.text:
• TODO: Finish writing this

Democratic centralism is the foundational organizational principle underlying DRUIDS. It provides a framework for collective decision-making combined with unified action, balancing democratic participation with effective implementation.

docs.title: Core Principles
docs.text: Democratic centralism is commonly misunderstood as a system of authoritarianism, but it is actually a system of democracy. Centralism and democracy are not opposites in contradiction, but they do exist in a dialectic relationship. Centralism relies upon democracy to remain abreast of the needs of the masses, to have accurate information, and to be able to make timely and effective decisions. Democracy relies on centralism for direction, guidance, and discipline. Centralism enhances democracy by providing the necessary structure to ensure that the will of the masses is properly represented and implemented.

docs.title: Freedom of Discussion
docs.text: Before decisions are made, all members have the right and responsibility to contribute to discussions. Once a decision is reached democratically, all members implement it with discipline, regardless of their personal position during the debate.

docs.title: Unity of Action
docs.text: Unity of action is the ability of the organization to move as one, to act in concert, to coordinate its actions, and to achieve its goals. It is the ability of the organization to move as one, to act in concert, to coordinate its actions, and to achieve its goals.

docs.title: Collective Decision-Making
docs.text: After thorough discussion, majority decisions become binding on all members. The minority maintains the right to hold their views internally but must implement the majority decision in practice.

docs.title: Reports from the Rank and File
How It Works in Practice
docs.text:
1. Proposal Submission

  2. Any member can submit proposals through defined channels

  3. Proposals must include rationale and implementation plans

  4. Security classification is assigned based on content

  5. Information Gathering

  6. Relevant data and perspectives are collected

  7. Subject matter experts provide input

  8. Historical precedents are reviewed

  9. Ideological Struggle

  10. Proposals are evaluated against organizational principles

  11. Members engage in structured discussion

  12. Different viewpoints are thoroughly explored

  13. Build Unity from Struggle

  14. Common ground is identified

  15. Compromise positions may be developed

  16. Final proposals are refined

  17. Voting

  18. Formal votes are conducted through secure channels

  19. Results are transparent to appropriate security levels

  20. Decisions are binding once made

  21. Implementation

  22. Clear responsibilities are assigned

  23. Timelines and metrics are established

  24. All members work toward the decided goal

  25. Accountability

  26. Progress is regularly reported

  27. Deviations are addressed through criticism/self-criticism
  28. Results are evaluated objectively

docs.title: Common Misconceptions
docs.text:
• It's Authoritarian - Democratic centralism requires MORE democracy than typical organizations, not less. Every decision involves genuine discussion before implementation.
  • It's Bureaucratic - Properly implemented, it prevents bureaucracy by ensuring leadership remains accountable to membership through regular criticism/self-criticism.
  • It's Inflexible - The system adapts to conditions. During high-security situations, it may emphasize centralism; during development periods, it may emphasize democracy.
  • It's Not Democratic - Democratic centralism is a system of democracy, not a system of authoritarianism.

docs.title: Revolutionary Aesthetics: The Visual Language of DRUIDS
Understanding Our Visual Philosophy
docs.text: The DRUIDS infrastructure isn't just a technical system—it's a revolutionary tool that requires a revolutionary aesthetic. Our visual design philosophy emerges from the intersection of historical socialist movements, modern digital accessibility, and the unique cultural context of Kansas radicalism.

docs.title: The Three Pillars of Our Aesthetic
1. Historical Continuity
docs.text:
We draw inspiration from the rich visual heritage of revolutionary movements:

  • Underground press aesthetics from the 1960s-70s radical newspapers
  • Soviet constructivist bold geometries and high contrast
  • Prairie populist pamphlets and broadsheets from Kansas history
  • International socialist iconography adapted for digital age

Our designs consciously reference this history not out of nostalgia, but to place our digital infrastructure within a continuum of revolutionary organizing tools.

docs.title: 2. Functional Security
docs.text:
Every visual element serves the dual purpose of aesthetics and operational security:

  • Color-coded security levels provide instant visual recognition
  • High contrast designs ensure readability under stress
  • Distinct theme variations for different security contexts
  • Visual consistency that builds trust and reduces errors

Security isn't an afterthought—it's woven into every pixel of our design language.

docs.title: 3. Accessible Rebellion
docs.text:
We reject the false choice between radical aesthetics and universal accessibility:

  • WCAG 2.1 AA compliance as a baseline, not a ceiling
  • Multiple sensory channels for critical information
  • Responsive design that works on any device a comrade might have
  • Print-ready formats for offline organizing

docs.title: Prairie Radical: The People's Interface
docs.text:
For public education and mass organizing

Imagine a weathered copy of "What Is To Be Done?" left on a Kansas farmhouse table, pages yellowed but words still burning bright. The Prairie Radical theme captures this essence—warm, approachable, yet unmistakably revolutionary.

The soft parchment backgrounds and muted red accents create a sense of historical weight without intimidation. Playfair Display headers evoke the gravitas of historical texts while remaining readable on modern screens. This is our teaching face—inviting newcomers while honoring our roots.

docs.title: Neobrutalist: The Urgent Call
docs.text:
For agitation and immediate action

Sometimes subtlety is complicity. The Neobrutalist theme screams urgency with warning yellow backgrounds that demand attention. Every element fights against corporate polish—borders are thick, shadows are harsh, images tilt at rebellious angles.

This aesthetic weaponizes discomfort. It tells users: "This matters. Pay attention. Act now." The intentional "ugliness" is a political choice, rejecting the slick interfaces that lull users into passive consumption.

docs.title: Mandalorian: The Technical Fortress
docs.text:
For internal operations and technical documentation

Named for the armor-clad warriors of popular fiction, this theme embodies resilience and technical competence. Dark slate backgrounds reduce eye strain during long working sessions, while "beskar green" accents provide just enough visual interest without distraction.

The scratched metal textures remind users they're working with tools forged in struggle. Bebas Neue headers give a retro-futuristic feel—we're building the future with the lessons of the past.

docs.title: The Revolutionary Color Palette
docs.text:
Our colors aren't arbitrary—each carries political and practical meaning:

  • Revolutionary Red (#CC3C3A): The blood of martyrs, the flag of liberation
  • Theory Black (#121212): The ink of manifestos, the night of clandestine meetings
  • Paper White (#F8F7F6): The blank page awaiting revolutionary words
  • Comrade Gold (#D6AA00): The wheat of collective harvest, the sun of new dawn
  • Warning Yellow (#FFE200): The alert of danger, the brightness of clarity
  • Beskar Green (#4a8b4a): The growth of movements, the strength of solidarity

docs.title: Visual Hierarchy as Political Statement
docs.text:
Our typography choices reflect organizational principles:

  • Headers (Spectral/Playfair/Bebas): Bold statements of principle
  • Body text (Inter): Clear communication for all literacy levels
  • Code (JetBrains Mono): Technical precision when needed

We reject:

  • Decorative fonts that prioritize aesthetics over readability
  • Corporate typefaces that carry capitalist baggage
  • Inconsistent styling that creates hierarchy where none should exist

docs.title: Security Through Design
docs.text:
The three-tier security visualization isn't just functional—it's pedagogical:

  • L0 Blue: Open as the sky, free as public discourse
  • L1 Amber: Caution like a traffic light, member trust required
  • L2 Red: Stop and think, operational security critical

These aren't just colors—they're training tools that build security culture through repetition.

docs.title: The Politics of Pixels
docs.text:
Every design decision is political:

  • High contrast challenges ableist assumptions about "normal" vision
  • Responsive design resists the digital divide
  • Print stylesheets honor offline organizing traditions
  • Theme switching respects user autonomy and context

We're not just building interfaces—we're encoding our values into the digital infrastructure of revolution.

docs.title: Living Design Language
docs.text:
This aesthetic system will evolve as our movement grows. What remains constant:

  1. Function over form—but form that inspires function
  2. Accessibility as solidarity—no comrade left behind
  3. Security as care—protecting each other through design
  4. History as teacher—learning from past struggles
  5. Future as motivation—building tools for victories to come

docs.title: Conclusion: More Than Skin Deep
docs.text:
The DRUIDS aesthetic isn't a coat of paint on standard software—it's the visual manifestation of our political principles. When a new member opens their first vault and sees the warm Prairie Radical theme, they're receiving a visual invitation to join a historical struggle. When an organizer switches to Neobrutalist for an urgent campaign, they're wielding design as a tool of agitation. When technical teams work in the Mandalorian interface, they're surrounded by reminders of the security and resilience their work requires.

This is revolutionary aesthetics: not just how our tools look, but how they make us feel, how they shape our work, and how they carry our values forward into every interaction.

The revolution will not be aestheticized—but revolutionary tools deserve revolutionary aesthetics.

docs.title: Security Concepts
docs.text:
• TODO: P1 Repair the doc id schema
  • TODO: Proof read this
  • TODO: Format correctly

Security is a fundamental part of DRUIDS. It is not just a technical issue, but a political issue. As we've stated previously, DRUIDS can handle some aspects of security, but it cannot do everything for you. It is important to emphasize repeatedly the lesson that the best form of security is having a correct political line. And while DRUIDS can help provide a framework to develop correct political lines, it is ultimately up to the members of the organization. We want to be clear that although DRUIDS is a powerful system when used correctly, it is not a panacea or a silver bullet. We want to be explicit about this, so that nobody is misled into thinking that DRUIDS is a magical talisman that will make your organization invulnerable to repression.

docs.title: What Is Security?
docs.text:
Security is the contradiction between the need to be open and accessible to the masses, and the need to protect our most sensitive information from nefarious adversaries. We have noticed some comrades, when assessing this dialectic, have a tendency to hyper-focus on the possibility of infiltration, and to be overly-paranoid about the possibility of being "caught" or "found out". This is a mistake. If we behave as if our enemy is all-powerful, all-seeing, and all knowing, then we have been defeated before the battle ever began. However, the opposite mode of thinking - that "If we're not doing anything illegal, then we have nothing to hide" is equally if not moreso ignorant! How do we navigate this dialectic?

Good security is a byproduct of correct politics. Consider the incident of Malinovsky and the Bolshevik Party. Malinovsky was a member of the Central Committee, and was also an Okrhana spy. Despite this level of infiltration, the Bolsheviks were successful in their revolution because they designed their organization so that cadres had to not only uphold a correct politcial line, but also had to be able to implement it in practice. If someone acts like a revolutionary, talks like a revolutionary, does revolutionary work, and avoids reactionary attitudes, then they can be said to be a revolutionary. DRUIDS cannot make you a revolutionary in word and deed. It cannot force anyone to act any kind of way. But it can help design an organization with structures that encourage and promote best revolutionary practices.

DRUIDS and the KSBC navigate this dialectic by emphasizing that we want to minimize security vulnerabilities while maximizing public accessibility, with public accessibility taking precedence over security vulnerabilities. We believe this min-maxing represents the ideal balance between the two sides of the dialectic. However, we also understand everyone's situation is different, and that there is no one-size-fits-all solution. Therefore, we leave it to each org to determine how they want to implement security policies. This will be discussed more in a future guide.

Is your organization of a clandestine nature? Then feel free to make use of the L2 classification. With DRUIDS, you could literally encrypt every single document and skip out on the public L0 classification if you so desire. Are you a mass organization who's more interested in the public visibility of your work? Then feel free to make use of the L0 classification and ignore the L2 encryption if that's what is best for your model.

docs.title: Methods
docs.text: Now that we've establish the dialectic of security, we can discuss the methods that we use to implement it. DRUIDS has two means of implementing and practicing security: administrative measures and technical measures. Again, we want to emphasize that good politics trumps both of these. But a computer program cannot do politics for you. However, a computer program can augment your poltiical work.

docs.title: Three-Tier Security Model
docs.text:
• L0 (Public): Information safe for public consumption
  • L1 (Candidate): Information for members in training
  • L2 (Cadre): Sensitive information for core members only

Each security level is segregated into its own directory, completely isolated from the others. Each directory is controlled by different levels of IAP. L0 is considered public knowledge, and we broadast this openly on public websites accessible to the masses - including cops. L1 represents a middle ground between public and private. While we don't require encryption of this information, we do restrict access to it based on an access control list which is managed by the cadre. L2 then represents the most sensitive information, and is only accessible to the cadre. We enforce this technologically through the use of hardware encryption keys. DRUIDS manually encrypts and decrypts file on the fly, and this is readily available in our source code for skeptics to verify.

We will not go into the specific details of the KSBC specific security logic, but what KSBC will say here is that on the whole, we classify 85% of what we do as L0. L1 is about 10% of what we do, and the L2 classification only applies to maybe 5% what we do. Other orgs are free to implement their own ratios as they see fit. We simply make the tools available to you, but we do not dictate how you should use them.

docs.title: Need-to-Know Principle
docs.text: Information is shared only with those who require it for their work, regardless of their general security clearance.

docs.title: Compartmentalization
docs.text: Separation of different types of information and work to limit exposure if security is breached.

docs.title: Understanding Security Tiers
docs.text:
• TODO: Proof read this
  • TODO: Format correctly

docs.title: Why Three Tiers?
docs.text: DRUIDS implements a three-tier security model to balance openness with operational security. This isn't about secrecy for its own sake - it's about protecting members while maintaining transparency where possible.

docs.title: L0 - Public (vault/public)
docs.text:
This level represents information safe for public consumption.

Examples:

  • Educational materials
  • Public meeting announcements
  • General organizational principles
  • This documentation

Why do we use it? Socialist organizations should educate and engage with the masses. The vast majority of your orgs materials should be this level! L0 content serves this mission.

docs.title: L1 - Member (vault/member)
docs.text:
Internal organizational information

Examples:

  • Meeting minutes with member names
  • Internal discussions
  • Organizational contacts
  • Development plans

Why it exists: Members need a space for frank discussion without public scrutiny. This allows for honest debate and protects member privacy.

docs.title: L2 - Cadre (vault/cadre)
docs.text:
What it is: Sensitive operational information Who has access: Limited, need-to-know basis Management: Completely separated from automated systems

Why it exists: Every organization needs to protect its most sensitive information. L2 ensures operational security.

docs.title: Implementation Through Git
docs.text:
Rather than complex permission systems, DRUIDS uses separate Git repositories:

vault/
├── public/     # Separate repo, public access
├── member/     # Separate repo, member access
└── cadre/      # Separate repo, restricted access

Benefits:

  • Clear boundaries - you can't accidentally commit to the wrong tier
  • Simple access control via GitHub permissions
  • Easy to audit who has access to what
  • No complex permission systems to maintain

docs.title: Document Headers
docs.text:
Every document includes security classification:

---
security: member
---

docs.title: Validation
docs.text:
Git hooks prevent committing documents to the wrong repository:

  • L1 document in public repo = rejected
  • Missing security classification = rejected
  • Mismatched classification = warning

docs.title: Workflow Integration
docs.text:
• GitHub Actions respect security boundaries
  • Public website only pulls from vault/public
  • Meeting minutes workflow creates L1 discussions

docs.text:
// Fort Knox plugin structure
class FortKnox {
  constructor() {
    this.securityLevels = ['L0', 'L1', 'L2'];
    this.documentTypes = ['proposal', 'meeting', 'report'];
  }

  validateDocument(file) {
    // Check frontmatter
    const fm = this.getFrontmatter(file);

    // Validate security level
    if (!this.securityLevels.includes(fm.security)) {
      throw new Error(`Invalid security: ${fm.security}`);
    }

    // Check file location matches security
    const path = file.path;
    const expectedSecurity = this.getSecurityFromPath(path);
    if (fm.security !== expectedSecurity) {
      throw new Error('Security mismatch');
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Example: Auto-Classification Plugin
docs.text:
import { Plugin, Notice } from 'obsidian';

export default class AutoClassifier extends Plugin {
  async onload() {
    // Listen for file creation
    this.registerEvent(
      this.app.vault.on('create', (file) => {
        this.classifyFile(file);
      })
    );
  }

  async classifyFile(file) {
    const path = file.path;
    let security = 'L0';

    if (path.includes('member')) security = 'L1';
    if (path.includes('cadre')) security = 'L2';

    // Update frontmatter
    await this.app.fileManager.processFrontMatter(
      file,
      (fm) => {
        fm.security = security;
        fm.classified_at = new Date().toISOString();
      }
    );

    new Notice(`Classified as ${security}`);
  }
}

docs.title: Security Scanner
docs.text:
// scripts/security-scanner.js
const fs = require('fs');
const path = require('path');
const matter = require('gray-matter');

function scanVault(vaultPath, expectedSecurity) {
  const issues = [];

  function scanDir(dir) {
    const files = fs.readdirSync(dir);

    files.forEach(file => {
      const fullPath = path.join(dir, file);
      const stat = fs.statSync(fullPath);

      if (stat.isDirectory() && !file.startsWith('.')) {
        scanDir(fullPath);
      } else if (file.endsWith('.md')) {
        const content = fs.readFileSync(fullPath, 'utf8');
        const { data } = matter(content);

        if (data.security !== expectedSecurity) {
          issues.push({
            file: fullPath,
            expected: expectedSecurity,
            actual: data.security
          });
        }
      }
    });
  }

  scanDir(vaultPath);
  return issues;
}

// Run scan
const publicIssues = scanVault('./vault/public', 'L0');
if (publicIssues.length > 0) {
  console.error('Security violations found:', publicIssues);
  process.exit(1);
}

// ✅ Good: Clear, documented, secure
export function generateDocumentId(type, security) {
  if (!VALID_TYPES.includes(type)) {
    throw new Error(`Invalid type: ${type}`);
  }

  const prefix = TYPE_PREFIXES[type];
  const date = new Date();
  const sequence = getNextSequence(type);

  return `${prefix}-${date.getFullYear()}-${sequence}-${security}`;
}

// ❌ Bad: Unclear, undocumented, insecure
export function genId(t, s) {
  return t + '-' + Date.now() + '-' + s;
}

docs.title: The Traffic Light Method
docs.text:
🟢 Green = Go (share freely)
🟡 Yellow = Yield (members only)  
🔴 Red = Stop (restricted access)

Teaching Script: "Imagine each document as having a traffic light. Green means anyone can see it - like a public flyer. Yellow means slow down - only members should see this, like meeting minutes. Red means stop - highly restricted, like security plans."

- Living room (L1) = Where members gather

docs.title: The Photo Album Analogy
docs.text: "Git is like a photo album that never forgets. Every time you save, it takes a snapshot. You can always go back and see what things looked like last week, last month, or last year."

docs.title: Key Concepts Simplified

  • Push = Putting album in shared library

  2. Discussion: 'What kind? When? Where?'
  3. Decision: 'Vegetarian potluck, Saturday, 6pm'
  4. Unity: Everyone brings vegetarian dishes
  5. Review: 'How did it go? Improvements?'"

docs.title: Identity Scrambling Techniques
docs.text: This is an L1 (Member-only) document. These techniques go beyond basic pseudonyms to provide comprehensive identity protection for members engaged in revolutionary organizing.

docs.title: Why Identity Scrambling Matters
docs.text:
State and corporate surveillance capabilities grow daily. A single slip-up can connect your revolutionary activities to your legal identity, leading to:

  • Employment termination
  • State harassment or prosecution
  • Doxxing by fascist groups
  • Social/family consequences

Identity scrambling creates multiple layers of protection, making it exponentially harder to connect your various activities.

docs.title: The Compartmentalization Principle
docs.text:
Never use the same pseudonym across different security contexts:

Legal Name: [NEVER USE]
     ↓
KSBC Work: "RedFox"
     ↓
Public Writing: "Prairie Voice"  
     ↓
Social Media: "Midwest Organizer"
     ↓
Other Groups: "Comrade Seven"

docs.title: Implementation
docs.text:
• Unique per project: Different revolutionary groups = different names
  • Unique per platform: GitHub vs Signal vs Forums
  • Unique per role: Public spokesperson vs internal organizer
  • Document privately: Keep a secure (encrypted) record of which identity is used where

docs.title: Stylometric Fingerprinting
docs.text:
AI can identify authors by analyzing:

  • Vocabulary choices
  • Sentence structure
  • Punctuation habits
  • Common phrases

docs.title: Techniques to Vary Style
docs.text:
For Public Documents:

  • Use formal, academic tone
  • Longer sentences with subclauses
  • Avoid personal anecdotes
  • Heavy use of passive voice

For Internal Documents:

  • More casual, direct tone
  • Shorter, punchy sentences
  • Include relevant examples
  • Active voice preferred

Style Switching Checklist:

  • Change sentence length patterns
  • Rotate vocabulary (use thesaurus)
  • Vary punctuation style
  • Alter paragraph structure
  • Switch between US/UK spelling

docs.title: The Problem
docs.text:
Regular commit patterns reveal timezone and work schedule:

Mon-Fri: commits 6-8pm → Evening worker in CST
Sat-Sun: commits 10am-2pm → Weekend schedule

docs.title: Solution: Time Scrambling
docs.text:
Manual Method:

# Commit with custom timestamp (±2 hours)
GIT_AUTHOR_DATE="2025-06-30 14:30:00" git commit -m "Update"

# Or use a random offset
OFFSET=$((RANDOM % 240 - 120))  # ±2 hours in minutes
NEW_TIME=$(date -d "$OFFSET minutes" '+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')
GIT_AUTHOR_DATE="$NEW_TIME" git commit -m "Update"

Automated Script (add to .bashrc):

git-commit-random() {
    # Random offset ±2 hours
    OFFSET=$((RANDOM % 240 - 120))
    NEW_TIME=$(date -d "$OFFSET minutes" '+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')
    GIT_AUTHOR_DATE="$NEW_TIME" GIT_COMMITTER_DATE="$NEW_TIME" git commit "$@"
}

docs.title: VPN + Tor for Git Operations
docs.text:
Basic Setup:

  1. VPN → Changes your IP location
  2. Tor → Adds additional anonymity layer
  3. Git over Tor → Maximum protection

Configuration:

# Configure Git to use Tor
git config --global http.proxy socks5://127.0.0.1:9050
git config --global https.proxy socks5://127.0.0.1:9050

# For SSH operations
# Add to ~/.ssh/config:
Host github.com
    ProxyCommand nc -x 127.0.0.1:9050 %h %p

docs.title: Rotation Strategy
docs.text:

  • Use different VPN providers for different projects
  • Avoid patterns (same server every Tuesday)

docs.text:

  • KSBC laptop: Revolutionary work only
  • Public device: For spaces/cafes

docs.title: Virtual Separation (Good)
docs.text:

  • Separate user accounts on same machine
  • Different browsers per identity

docs.title: Account Separation
docs.text:
• Separate email addresses per identity
  • Different password managers
  • No cross-identity bookmarks
  • Distinct browser profiles

docs.title: Cross-Contamination Prevention
docs.text:
• Never "follow" your other identities
  • Don't share content between identities
  • Avoid similar profile photos
  • Different posting schedules

docs.title: Digital Footprint Reduction
docs.text:
• Regularly delete old posts
  • Use disappearing messages
  • Avoid location tags
  • Disable read receipts

docs.title: When to Burn an Identity
docs.text:
• Suspected compromise
  • Accidental real name use
  • Cross-contamination detected
  • Operation completed

docs.title: Burn Procedure
docs.text:
1. Stop all activity immediately
  2. Archive important data (encrypted)
  3. Delete accounts in reverse chronological order
  4. Wipe devices used with that identity
  5. Wait period before creating new identity
  6. Never reuse any aspect of burned identity

shred -vfz sensitive-file

# Wipe free space
# Linux:
dd if=/dev/urandom of=tempfile bs=1M; rm tempfile

# Full disk wipe (WARNING: Destroys everything)
# dd if=/dev/urandom of=/dev/sdX bs=1M

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This tutorial walks you through setting up and using MkDocs to build the DRUIDS documentation website. You'll learn how to install MkDocs, configure it for our project, and build/deploy the documentation site.

Key Learning: This tutorial reflects real-world experience from implementing DRUIDS documentation. We'll show you both the ideal path and common pitfalls to avoid.

Success Pattern: Start with Material theme + custom CSS rather than building custom themes from scratch. This approach delivers professional results in minutes rather than hours of debugging.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.8 or higher
  • pip (Python package manager)
  • Git
  • Text editor

docs.title: 1. Install MkDocs and Dependencies
docs.text:
Recommended Approach (Battle-tested for DRUIDS):

# Create a virtual environment (highly recommended)
python -m venv mkdocs-env
source mkdocs-env/bin/activate  # On Windows: mkdocs-env\Scripts\activate

# Install Material theme (includes MkDocs + all dependencies)
pip install mkdocs-material

# Optional: Additional plugins for enhanced features
pip install mkdocs-git-revision-date-localized-plugin

# Verify installation
mkdocs --version
# Should show: mkdocs, version 1.6.1+

Why Material theme first?

  • Installing mkdocs-material automatically includes MkDocs core
  • Includes all required pymdownx extensions
  • Avoids dependency conflicts that cause "cannot find module" errors
  • Provides proven, working navigation (no dropdown issues)

Common Installation Issues:

# Error: "cannot find module 'pymdownx'"
# Solution: Install material theme (includes pymdownx)
pip install mkdocs-material

# Error: "cannot find module 'materialx.emoji'"
# This indicates wrong emoji configuration - we'll fix in config section

docs.title: 2. Clone the DRUIDS Documentation
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/ks-sbc/druids-wiki.git
cd druids-wiki

docs.title: 1. Start the Development Server
docs.text:
Basic Local Development:

# Navigate to the project directory
cd druids-wiki

# Start the development server
mkdocs serve

# You should see:
# INFO    -  Building documentation...
# INFO    -  Cleaning site directory
# INFO    -  Documentation built in 0.45 seconds
# INFO    -  [10:30:45] Serving on http://127.0.0.1:8000/

For Team Development (DRUIDS Recommended):

# External access for team collaboration
mkdocs serve --dev-addr=0.0.0.0:8001

# Now accessible at:
# - http://localhost:8001 (your machine)
# - http://YOUR_IP:8001 (other team members)

Development Server Features:

  • 🔄 Live reload - Changes appear instantly
  • 🚀 Fast builds - Rebuilds only changed files
  • ⚠️ Link validation - Shows broken links as warnings
  • 🔍 Search indexing - Updates search automatically

Open your browser to see the documentation site with working navigation!

docs.title: 2. Make Changes and See Live Updates
docs.text:
1. Edit a documentation file (e.g., docs/index.md)
  2. Save the file
  3. Watch the browser automatically refresh with your changes

This live-reload feature makes it easy to write and preview documentation simultaneously.

docs.title: 3. Build the Static Site
docs.text:
# Build production-ready site
mkdocs build

# This creates a 'site' directory with HTML files
ls site/
# You'll see: index.html, assets/, stylesheets/, etc.

docs.title: Understanding mkdocs.yml
docs.text:
The mkdocs.yml file in the project root controls how your documentation is built.

DRUIDS Production Configuration (Battle-tested):

# Basic site information
site_name: DRUIDS Wiki
site_description: Kansas Socialist Book Club's documentation for DRUIDS

# Essential plugins (minimal, reliable set)
plugins:
  - search    # Built-in search functionality

# Custom CSS for DRUIDS revolutionary aesthetics
extra_css:
  - stylesheets/druids-material.css

# Theme configuration (proven to work)
theme:
  name: material
  features:
    - navigation.tabs         # Top-level tabs (fixes dropdown issues)
    - navigation.sections     # Section grouping
    - navigation.expand       # Auto-expand navigation
    - navigation.path         # Breadcrumb navigation
    - navigation.top          # Back to top button
    - search.highlight        # Highlight search terms
    - search.share           # Shareable search URLs
    - content.code.copy      # Copy buttons for code blocks

  # DRUIDS revolutionary color scheme
  palette:
    - scheme: slate           # Dark theme (primary)
      primary: green          # Forest green
      accent: amber           # Earth tone accent
      toggle:
        icon: material/brightness-4
        name: Switch to light mode
    - scheme: default         # Light theme (fallback)
      primary: green
      accent: amber
      toggle:
        icon: material/brightness-7
        name: Switch to dark mode

  font:
    text: Inter             # Clean, readable font
    code: JetBrains Mono    # Monospace for code

# Markdown extensions (essential set)
markdown_extensions:
  - abbr              # Abbreviation definitions
  - admonition        # Call-out boxes
  - attr_list         # HTML attributes in Markdown
  - def_list          # Definition lists
  - footnotes         # Footnote references
  - md_in_html        # Markdown inside HTML
  - toc:              # Table of contents
      permalink: true # Anchor links for headings
  - pymdownx.superfences:   # Enhanced code blocks
      custom_fences:
        - name: mermaid     # Diagram support
          class: mermaid
          format: !!python/name:pymdownx.superfences.fence_code_format
  - pymdownx.highlight      # Syntax highlighting
  - pymdownx.details       # Collapsible sections
  - pymdownx.tasklist:     # Task lists
      custom_checkbox: true
  - pymdownx.emoji:        # Emoji support (fixed config)
      emoji_generator: !!python/name:pymdownx.emoji.to_svg
      emoji_index: !!python/name:pymdownx.emoji.twemoji

# Navigation structure (Diátaxis framework)
nav:
  - Home: index.md
  - Tutorials:
    - Getting Started: tutorials/getting-started.md
    - MkDocs Setup: tutorials/mkdocs-setup-guide.md
  - How-To:
    - Meeting Minutes: how-to/create-meeting-minutes.md
  - Reference:
    - Overview: reference/index.md
    - MkDocs Technical: reference/mkdocs-technical-reference.md
  - Explanation:
    - Overview: explanation/_index.md
    - Why DRUIDS: explanation/why-druids-matters.md

Configuration Lessons Learned:

  • ✅ Use navigation.tabs - Solves dropdown menu issues
  • ✅ Minimal plugin set - Reduces complexity and conflicts
  • ✅ Fixed emoji config - Prevents "materialx" module errors
  • ✅ Custom CSS overlay - Revolutionary aesthetics without theme complexity
  • ❌ Avoid navigation.instant - Can break custom CSS
  • ❌ Avoid complex plugin chains - Increases debugging overhead

docs.title: Privacy & Pseudonym Quick Start Guide
docs.text:
• TODO: Proof read this
  • TODO: Format correctly

Why This Matters: Revolutionary organizations face real surveillance threats. Using pseudonyms protects members from doxxing, employer retaliation, and state monitoring. This is not paranoia—it's operational security.

docs.title: 1. Choose Your Pseudonym (2 minutes)
docs.text:
Pick a code name that:

  • ✅ Is memorable but not personally identifying
  • ✅ Doesn't hint at your real identity
  • ✅ You can use consistently

Good Examples:

  • RedFox
  • Agent7
  • Comrade191
  • BlueSparrow

Bad Examples:

  • JohnFromKansas (location info)
  • Teacher2020 (profession hint)
  • Mike_S (partial real name)

docs.title: 2. Configure Git (3 minutes)
docs.text:
Open your terminal and run these commands:

# Set your pseudonym as Git author
git config --global user.name "YourPseudonym"

# Use generic organizational email
git config --global user.email "member@ksbc.org"

# Verify your settings
git config --list | grep user

Important: This affects ALL your Git repositories. For KSBC-only pseudonym:

# Navigate to your KSBC repository first
cd /path/to/ksbc/repo

# Set config for this repository only (no --global)
git config user.name "YourPseudonym"
git config user.email "member@ksbc.org"

docs.title: ❌ Don't Use Your GitHub Username
docs.text: Your GitHub profile might have real information. Use a different pseudonym for commits.

docs.title: ❌ Don't Reference Personal Details
docs.text:
Avoid pseudonyms like:

  • Birth years (Agent1995)
  • Locations (KansasComrade)
  • Interests that could identify you (GuitarMarxist)

docs.title: ❌ Don't Forget Other Repositories
docs.text:
If you contribute to multiple projects, decide whether to:

  • Use the same pseudonym everywhere (simpler)
  • Use different pseudonyms per project (more secure)

docs.title: ❌ Don't Put Real Names in Code Comments
docs.text:
Check your code for:

# Bad: Created by John Smith
# Good: Created for KSBC project

docs.title: 4. Quick Security Check
docs.text:
Run this command to see what name appears in your recent commits:

git log --format="%an <%ae>" -10

If you see your real name, you'll need to either:

  1. Start fresh with new commits using your pseudonym
  2. Clean your Git history (see Git History Scrubbing Guide)

docs.title: 5. Beyond Git: Document Privacy
docs.text:
When writing documentation:

  • Never include member real names
  • Use pseudonyms or roles ("the secretary", "a member")
  • Redact identifying information from screenshots
  • Check meeting minutes for accidental name drops

docs.title: 6. Emergency: I Accidentally Used My Real Name
docs.text:
Don't panic. Take these steps:

  1. Stop pushing commits immediately
  2. Check if it's pushed: git status
  3. If not pushed: Amend your last commit:
git commit --amend --author="YourPseudonym <member@ksbc.org>"
  1. If already pushed: Contact security team for Git history cleaning

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Configure your Git settings now
  • Check your recent commits for real names
  • Review any documents you've written
  • Read the Identity Scrambling Guide for advanced protection

# Check current config
git config user.name
git config user.email

# Check recent commits
git log --format="%an <%ae>" -10

# Fix last commit (if not pushed)
git commit --amend --author="YourPseudonym <member@ksbc.org>"

Remember: Good security is a practice, not a one-time setup. Stay vigilant!

docs.title: 2. Main Content Template (main.html)
docs.text:
{% extends "base.html" %}

{% block content %}
<div class="container">
    <!-- Security indicator based on page metadata -->
    {% if page and page.meta and page.meta.security %}
        <div class="security-indicator security-{{ page.meta.security|lower }}">
            <span class="security-badge">{{ page.meta.security }}</span>
        </div>
    {% endif %}

    <!-- Breadcrumbs -->
    <nav class="breadcrumb" aria-label="breadcrumb">
        <ol>
            <li><a href="{{ config.site_url }}">Home</a></li>
            {% if page %}
                {% for doc in page.ancestors %}
                    <li><a href="{{ doc.url|url }}">{{ doc.title }}</a></li>
                {% endfor %}
                <li class="active">{{ page.title }}</li>
            {% endif %}
        </ol>
    </nav>

    <!-- Page header -->
    <header class="page-header">
        <h1>{{ page.title }}</h1>
        {% if page and page.meta %}
            <div class="page-meta">
                {% if page.meta.date %}
                    <time datetime="{{ page.meta.date }}">{{ page.meta.date }}</time>
                {% endif %}
                {% if page.meta.authors %}
                    <span class="authors">By {{ page.meta.authors|join(', ') }}</span>
                {% endif %}
            </div>
        {% endif %}
    </header>

    <!-- Table of contents -->
    {% if page.toc %}
        <nav class="toc" aria-label="Table of contents">
            <h2>Contents</h2>
            <ul>
                {% for item in page.toc %}
                    <li>
                        <a href="{{ item.url }}">{{ item.title }}</a>
                        {% if item.children %}
                            <ul>
                                {% for child in item.children %}
                                    <li><a href="{{ child.url }}">{{ child.title }}</a></li>
                                {% endfor %}
                            </ul>
                        {% endif %}
                    </li>
                {% endfor %}
            </ul>
        </nav>
    {% endif %}

    <!-- Page content -->
    <article class="page-content">
        {{ page.content }}
    </article>

    <!-- Page navigation -->
    <nav class="page-nav">
        {% if page.previous_page %}
            <a href="{{ page.previous_page.url|url }}" class="nav-prev">
                ← {{ page.previous_page.title }}
            </a>
        {% endif %}
        {% if page.next_page %}
            <a href="{{ page.next_page.url|url }}" class="nav-next">
                {{ page.next_page.title }} →
            </a>
        {% endif %}
    </nav>
</div>
{% endblock %}

/* Mandalorian Theme for MkDocs */

:root {
  /* Colors */
  --mando-bg-primary: #1a1d23;
  --mando-bg-secondary: #22252c;
  --mando-bg-tertiary: #2a2d35;
  --mando-text-primary: #e0e0e0;
  --mando-text-secondary: #b0b0b0;
  --mando-text-muted: #808080;
  --mando-accent-primary: #4a8b4a;
  --mando-accent-secondary: #c76e2e;
  --mando-border: #2d3137;

  /* Typography */
  --mando-font-heading: 'Bebas Neue', Arial, sans-serif;
  --mando-font-body: 'Inter', -apple-system, sans-serif;
  --mando-font-code: 'JetBrains Mono', monospace;

  /* Spacing */
  --mando-space-xs: 0.25rem;
  --mando-space-sm: 0.5rem;
  --mando-space-md: 1rem;
  --mando-space-lg: 1.5rem;
  --mando-space-xl: 2rem;
}

/* Base styles */
body.mandalorian-theme {
  background-color: var(--mando-bg-primary);
  color: var(--mando-text-primary);
  font-family: var(--mando-font-body);
  line-height: 1.6;
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
}

/* Metal texture overlay */
.metal-texture {
  position: fixed;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  background-image: url('../img/scratched-metal.svg');
  opacity: 0.03;
  pointer-events: none;
  z-index: 1;
}

/* Typography */
h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 {
  font-family: var(--mando-font-heading);
  text-transform: uppercase;
  letter-spacing: 0.1em;
  color: var(--mando-accent-primary);
  margin-top: var(--mando-space-xl);
  margin-bottom: var(--mando-space-md);
}

h1 { font-size: 2.5rem; }
h2 { font-size: 2rem; }
h3 { font-size: 1.75rem; }
h4 { font-size: 1.5rem; }
h5 { font-size: 1.25rem; }
h6 { font-size: 1rem; }

/* Links */
a {
  color: var(--mando-accent-primary);
  text-decoration: none;
  transition: color 0.2s ease;
}

a:hover {
  color: var(--mando-accent-secondary);
  text-decoration: underline;
}

/* Code blocks */
pre {
  background-color: #0d1117;
  border: 1px solid var(--mando-border);
  border-radius: 0.25rem;
  padding: var(--mando-space-md);
  overflow-x: auto;
}

code {
  font-family: var(--mando-font-code);
  font-size: 0.9em;
  background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.05);
  padding: 0.125rem 0.25rem;
  border-radius: 0.125rem;
}

pre code {
  background-color: transparent;
  padding: 0;
}

/* Navigation */
.site-nav {
  background-color: var(--mando-bg-secondary);
  border-bottom: 1px solid var(--mando-border);
  padding: var(--mando-space-md);
  position: sticky;
  top: 0;
  z-index: 100;
}

/* Content container */
.container {
  max-width: 1200px;
  margin: 0 auto;
  padding: var(--mando-space-lg);
}

/* Page content */

docs.title: Theme JavaScript (js/theme.js)
docs.text:
// Mandalorian Theme JavaScript

(function() {
  'use strict';

  // Security level detection
  function detectSecurityLevel() {
    const path = window.location.pathname;
    if (path.includes('/public/')) return 'l0';
    if (path.includes('/member/')) return 'l1';
    if (path.includes('/cadre/')) return 'l2';
    return 'l0'; // default
  }

  // Apply security class to body
  document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {
    const securityLevel = detectSecurityLevel();
    document.body.classList.add(`security-${securityLevel}`);

    // Add visual indicator if not already present
    const mainContent = document.querySelector('.page-content');
    if (mainContent && !document.querySelector('.security-indicator')) {
      const indicator = document.createElement('div');
      indicator.className = `security-indicator security-${securityLevel}`;
      indicator.innerHTML = `<span class="security-badge">${securityLevel.toUpperCase()}</span>`;
      mainContent.parentNode.insertBefore(indicator, mainContent);
    }
  });

  // Smooth scroll for anchor links
  document.querySelectorAll('a[href^="#"]').forEach(anchor => {
    anchor.addEventListener('click', function(e) {
      e.preventDefault();
      const target = document.querySelector(this.getAttribute('href'));
      if (target) {
        target.scrollIntoView({ behavior: 'smooth' });
      }
    });
  });

  // Code block enhancements
  document.querySelectorAll('pre code').forEach(block => {
    // Add line numbers
    const lines = block.textContent.split('\n');
    if (lines.length > 1) {
      block.classList.add('line-numbers');
    }

    // Add copy button
    const button = document.createElement('button');
    button.className = 'copy-code';
    button.textContent = 'Copy';
    button.addEventListener('click', function() {
      navigator.clipboard.writeText(block.textContent);
      button.textContent = 'Copied!';
      setTimeout(() => button.textContent = 'Copy', 2000);
    });
    block.parentNode.appendChild(button);
  });
})();

Consolidated Documentation

This guide consolidates all Git workflow information for DRUIDS, including content previously in separate files for Obsidian Git configuration, workflows, and offline usage. For specific Obsidian plugin configuration details, see the Obsidian Configuration section below.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This guide consolidates all Git workflow information for DRUIDS, covering automated synchronization, branch management for security tiers, pull request processes, conflict resolution, and commit signing. It's designed for both individual and collaborative vault management with a focus on security and democratic principles.

docs.title: Essential Commands
docs.text:
# Modern tool usage (preferred)
rg "pattern" --type md      # Search in markdown files
fd "*.md" docs/             # Find all markdown files
bat config.yaml             # View file with syntax highlighting

# Basic Git operations in Obsidian
"Obsidian Git: Pull"        # Fetch latest changes
"Obsidian Git: Commit all"  # Commit all changes
"Obsidian Git: Push"        # Push to remote

docs.title: Daily Workflow
docs.text:
1. Start of day: Pull latest changes
  2. During work: Commit regularly with meaningful messages
  3. Before sharing: Push changes to remote
  4. Switching tiers: Always commit first, then switch branches

docs.title: Setting Up Auto-Sync
docs.text:
1. Access Settings

  2. Open Obsidian → Settings → Community plugins → Obsidian Git

  3. Configure Intervals

Vault backup interval: 15  # minutes
Auto backup: ✓ enabled
Auto pull: ✓ enabled  
Auto push: ✓ enabled
  1. Set Commit Messages
# Good static messages
"chore: automatic vault sync"

  1. Enable Pull on Startup

docs.title: Prerequisites for Auto-Sync
docs.text:
• Git Authentication: SSH keys or credential manager configured
  • Remote Repository: Properly configured origin
  • No Conflicts: Resolved merge conflicts
  • Internet Connection: Stable connectivity

docs.title: Monitoring Auto-Sync
docs.text:
• Check status bar for sync indicators
  • Review commit history periodically
  • Watch for error notifications
  • Verify remote updates on GitHub

docs.title: Core Principles
docs.text:
1. Branch per Tier: Each security level has its own branch
  2. Default to Lowest: Stay on main (L0) unless needed
  3. Conscious Switching: Deliberate action for higher tiers
  4. No Merge Down: Never merge sensitive info to lower tiers
  5. Feature Branches: Create temporary branches for complex work

docs.title: main (L0 - Public)
docs.text:
Purpose: Public, unclassified information
Auto-sync: Safe to enable all features
Collaboration: Open to all members
Visual: 🟢 Green borders

docs.title: L1-internal (Member Only)
docs.text:
Purpose: Internal team information
Auto-sync: Consider manual push
Collaboration: Trusted members only
Visual: 🟤 Brown borders

Switching Protocol:
1. Commit all changes on current branch
2. "Obsidian Git: Checkout branch" → L1-internal
3. "Obsidian Git: Pull" immediately
4. Work on L1 content
5. Commit before switching back

docs.title: L2-secure (Highly Sensitive)
docs.text:
Purpose: Confidential, restricted information
Auto-sync: DISABLE auto-push, manual only
Collaboration: Minimal, need-to-know
Visual: 🔴 Red borders

Critical Rules:
- Double-check branch before every commit
- Review staged changes carefully
- Manual push only
- Consider local-only or encrypted remote

docs.title: Branch Switching Workflow
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[Current Branch] -->|1. Commit Changes| B[Clean State]
    B -->|2. Checkout New Branch| C[New Branch]
    C -->|3. Pull Latest| D[Updated Branch]
    D -->|4. Work & Commit| E[Changes Made]
    E -->|5. Push if Appropriate| F[Synced]

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
• Global Auto-Push: Be aware it affects ALL branches
  • Mitigation Options:
  • Disable global auto-push, use manual push for L1/L2
  • Temporarily disable before switching to sensitive branches
  • User Training: Essential for all vault users
  • Accidental Commits: Have remediation procedures ready

  4. Base: Target branch (main, L1-internal, etc.)

  • Create merge commit: Preserves all commits
  • Rebase and merge: Linear history (use cautiously)

Post-Merge:

  • All collaborators pull updates

    C -->|GitHub Action| D[Draft PR]

  • Validation before submission
  • Audit trail maintained
  • Manual review checkpoint

docs.title: Understanding Conflicts
docs.text:
Conflicts occur when:

  • Same lines modified in different ways
  • Pulling changes that conflict with local edits
  • Merging branches with overlapping changes

Your local version
=======
Incoming version
>>>>>>> branch-name

docs.title: Why Sign Commits?
docs.text:
• Authenticity: Proves you made the commit
  • Integrity: Ensures commit hasn't been altered
  • Trust: Critical for sensitive branches (L1/L2)

docs.title: 1. System Configuration
docs.text:
# Install GPG
gpg --version

# Generate or import key
gpg --full-generate-key

# List keys
gpg --list-secret-keys --keyid-format LONG

# Configure Git
git config --global user.signingkey YOUR_KEY_ID
git config --global commit.gpgsign true
git config --global tag.gpgsign true

docs.title: 2. GPG Agent Setup
docs.text:
Essential for automated signing:

# Add to shell profile
export GPG_TTY=$(tty)

# Configure agent to cache passphrase
# Allows background signing

docs.title: Hardware Security Keys
docs.text:
For maximum security on L2 branches:

  • Store GPG key on YubiKey/Nitrokey
  • Key never leaves hardware
  • Physical touch required to sign

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
# Check local signatures
git log --show-signature

# GitHub shows "Verified" badge
# Upload public key to GitHub

docs.title: Important Limitations
docs.text:
• Mobile: Signing not supported on iOS/Android
  • Automation: Requires GPG agent for auto-commits
  • Complexity: Advanced feature, team training needed

docs.title: Security-First Approach
docs.text:
1. Always verify branch before committing
  2. Review changes before pushing sensitive branches
  3. Use visual indicators as primary guide
  4. Manual push for L2 content
  5. Sign commits on sensitive branches

docs.title: Collaboration Guidelines
docs.text:
1. Clear commit messages describing changes
  2. Small, focused commits over large changes
  3. Comprehensive PR descriptions
  4. Constructive review feedback
  5. Prompt response to review requests

docs.title: Automation Balance
docs.text:
1. Enable auto-sync for public branches
  2. Manual control for sensitive content
  3. Monitor status regularly
  4. Test authentication periodically
  5. Document exceptions to standard workflow

docs.title: Migration Guide: From Google Docs to DRUIDS
docs.text: Most organizations complete migration in one weekend. This guide shows you how, without losing data or disrupting work.

docs.title: You're Ready to Migrate If
docs.text: ✅ Someone burned out from password management ✅ Can't find last month's meeting notes ✅ Worried about Google reading everything ✅ New members confused about where things are ✅ Just tired of the chaos

docs.title: You're NOT Ready If
docs.text: ❌ No one sees the current system as broken ❌ Can't dedicate one weekend to migration ❌ No technical champion identified ❌ Active crisis requiring all hands

docs.title: Step 1.1: Document Inventory Checklist
docs.text:
Create a spreadsheet listing:

Document Name | Location | Last Updated | Security Level | Owner
-----------|----------|--------------|----------------|-------
Meeting Minutes 2024 | Sarah's Drive | Nov 2024 | L1 | Sarah
Budget 2024 | Shared Drive | Oct 2024 | L1 | Treasury
Flyer Templates | Mike's Drive | Sep 2024 | L0 | Outreach
Action Plans | Signal chat | ??? | L2 | Various

Common Locations to Check:

  • Personal Google Drives (each member)
  • Shared Drives
  • Google Groups
  • Email attachments
  • Signal/Discord pinned messages
  • That one person's laptop

docs.title: Step 1.2: Quick Security Classification
docs.text:
For each document, ask:

  1. Is it already public? → L0 (Green)
  2. Would exposure harm org but not people? → L1 (Brown)
  3. Could someone get arrested/fired? → L2 (Red)

Classification Shortcuts:

  • Meeting agendas → L0
  • Meeting minutes (full) → L1
  • Member lists → L1
  • Financial records → L1
  • Action planning → L2
  • Legal defense → L2

docs.title: Step 1.3: Team Readiness Check
docs.text:
Technical Champion Checklist:

  • Comfortable with basic Git (or willing to learn)
  • Can dedicate weekend to migration
  • Patient with non-technical members
  • Has admin access to Google accounts

Team Communication:

Subject: Document Migration This Weekend

Comrades,

We're moving from Google Docs to DRUIDS this weekend to solve our 
"one person has all passwords" problem. 

What you need to do:
1. List any important docs you have by Friday night
2. Be available Saturday for questions
3. Join training session Sunday 2pm

This will make everyone's life easier - promise!

[Technical Champion Name]

docs.title: Step 2.1: Bulk Export from Google
docs.text:
Using Google Takeout (Recommended):

  1. Go to takeout.google.com
  2. Deselect all, then select only "Drive"
  3. Choose export format: .docx for docs, .xlsx for sheets
  4. Export frequency: One-time
  5. File type: .zip, 2GB segments
  6. Wait for email (usually 1-2 hours)

Manual Export (For Specific Folders):

  1. Open Google Drive
  2. Right-click folder → Download
  3. Converts to Office formats automatically

docs.title: Step 2.2: Convert to Markdown
docs.text:
Automated Conversion:

# Install pandoc (one-time)
# Mac: brew install pandoc
# Linux: sudo apt install pandoc
# Windows: Download from pandoc.org

# Convert all docs to markdown
find ./GoogleExport -name "*.docx" -exec \
  pandoc -f docx -t markdown {} -o {}.md \;

Manual Conversion Options:

  • Docs to Markdown add-on
  • Copy-paste into Obsidian (handles formatting)
  • MarkdownConverter.com for one-offs

├── L0-public/
│   ├── education/
│   ├── flyers/
│   └── public-statements/
├── L1-member/

│   └── internal-docs/

grep -l "meeting minutes" *.md | xargs -I {} mv {} ./L1-member/meeting-minutes/
grep -l "public" *.md | xargs -I {} mv {} ./L0-public/
grep -l "action\|legal\|security" *.md | xargs -I {} mv {} ./L2-cadre/

docs.title: Security Implementation Playbook
docs.text: Real security for small revolutionary organizations - Not paranoia, not theater, just practical protection against documented threats.

docs.title: Part 1: Threat Model Reality Check (30 minutes)
docs.text:
Exercise: List Your Actual Threats

Get your core organizers together and honestly assess:

  1. Law Enforcement Threats
  2. Local police interest level (Low/Medium/High)
  3. Federal attention (FBI, DHS, etc.)
  4. Past raids or surveillance in your area

  5. Legal vulnerabilities (arrests, warrants)

  6. Corporate/Employer Threats

  7. Members' job security risks
  8. Corporate surveillance concerns

  9. Industry-specific retaliation

  10. Internal Threats

  11. Burnout and single points of failure
  12. Information silos
  13. Personality conflicts

  14. Potential infiltration

  15. Technical Threats

  16. Device seizure likelihood
  17. Hacking sophistication needed
  18. Social engineering risks

Output: Threat priority list (what keeps you up at night?)

docs.title: Part 2: Map Threats to Security Tiers (45 minutes)
docs.text:
Use this classification flowchart:

Is this information already public or meant to be?
    YES → L0 (Green) - Public Tier
    NO ↓

Would disclosure harm the organization but not individuals?
    YES → L1 (Brown) - Member Tier  
    NO ↓

Could this get someone arrested, fired, or physically harmed?
    YES → L2 (Red) - Cadre Tier

Common L0 (Public) Examples:

  • Educational materials
  • Public event announcements
  • Already-published positions
  • General meeting minutes (sanitized)

Common L1 (Member) Examples:

  • Internal discussions and debates
  • Member contact information
  • Financial records
  • Strategic planning (non-sensitive)
  • Meeting minutes (full version)

Common L2 (Cadre) Examples:

  • Direct action planning
  • Legal defense strategies
  • Infiltration concerns
  • Member vulnerabilities
  • Anything involving illegality

docs.title: Part 3: Implement Practical Security (45 minutes)
docs.text:
Immediate Actions (Do Today):

  1. Password Audit
  2. List all organizational accounts
  3. Identify who has access
  4. Create password manager vault

  5. Generate new strong passwords

  6. Communication Channels

  7. Public: Keep Discord/social media
  8. Member: Move to DRUIDS L1 vault

  9. Sensitive: Create L2 procedures

  10. Document Migration

  11. Export Google Docs
  12. Sort by security tier
  13. Import to appropriate vaults

This Week Actions:

  1. Device Security Basics
# Minimum viable security
- Full disk encryption on all devices
- Screen lock with password (not biometric)
- Separate user accounts for DRUIDS work
- Regular backups to encrypted drives
  1. Access Control Setup
  2. L0: Anyone can clone public repo
  3. L1: Member onboarding checklist

  4. L2: Strict need-to-know basis

  5. Visual Security Training

  6. Show green/brown/red borders

  8. Common mistakes workshop

docs.title: Before (Preparation)
docs.text:

Organizational Preparation:

docs.title: During (If Raid Happens)
docs.text:
Immediate Response:

  1. Stay Calm - They want you panicked
  2. Invoke Rights - "I am exercising my right to remain silent. I want a lawyer."
  3. Document Everything - Have someone outside filming/noting
  4. Alert Network - Use predetermined signal

Technical Response:

  • Do NOT unlock devices
  • Do NOT provide passwords
  • Do NOT consent to searches
  • Let encryption do its job

First 24 Hours:

  • Account for all members

First Week:

  • Change all L1 passwords
  • Rotate L2 access completely

docs.title: Make It Visual, Not Verbal
docs.text:
❌ Security Theater:

  • Complex passwords changed monthly
  • Paranoid communication protocols
  • Assuming everything is compromised
  • Secret agent LARPing

✅ Real Security:

  • Visual indicators prevent mistakes
  • Reasonable practices people follow
  • Threat-appropriate responses
  • Community accountability

docs.title: Regular Security Reviews (Monthly)
docs.text:
10-Minute Security Check:

  1. Any new threats this month?
  2. Any classification confusion?
  3. Any close calls or mistakes?
  4. Anyone need security support?

Quarterly Deep Dive:

  • Review threat model changes
  • Update access lists
  • Practice incident response
  • Refresh training materials

docs.title: Common Pitfalls to Avoid
docs.text:
1. Over-Classification
  2. Not everything is L2
  3. Kills organizational transparency

  4. Creates unnecessary barriers

  5. Under-Classification

  6. "It's probably fine" isn't security
  7. One mistake can expose members

  8. Visual indicators exist for a reason

  9. Security Theater

  10. Complexity doesn't equal security
  11. Focus on real threats, not movie plots

  12. Sustainability beats perfection

  13. Single Security Officer

  14. Creates new single point of failure
  15. Burns out security-conscious members
  16. Everyone needs basic knowledge
