docs.title: Cultural Significance of the Queer Mandalorian Theme
Overview
docs.text: The Queer Mandalorian theme is more than a visual design—it's a statement of resistance, a celebration of chosen family, and a reclamation of technology as a tool for liberation. This document explores the deep cultural roots and revolutionary philosophy embedded in every design choice.

docs.title: The Fusion of Identities
docs.text: The theme represents a powerful fusion of four revolutionary identities:

docs.title: 1. Guerilla Warrior
docs.text:
• Resourcefulness: Making powerful tools from limited resources
  • Rebellion: Fighting from the margins against oppressive systems
  • Tactics: Asymmetric resistance through technology
  • Community: Small cells working toward collective liberation

docs.title: 2. Cyberpunk Ethos
docs.text:
• High Tech, Low Life: Advanced technology in the hands of the marginalized
  • Corporate Resistance: Fighting surveillance capitalism
  • Information Freedom: "Information wants to be free"
  • Digital Autonomy: Controlling our own digital spaces

docs.title: 3. Trans Hacker Culture
docs.text:
• Binary Breaking: Rejecting false dichotomies in code and life
  • Identity Hacking: Rewriting our own source code
  • Subversive Tech: Using master's tools to dismantle master's house
  • Collective Care: Building support networks through technology

docs.title: 4. Mandalorian Code
docs.text:
• Found Family: "This is the Way" - collective over individual
  • Honor Through Action: Deeds, not words
  • Protective Community: Defending the vulnerable
  • Cultural Preservation: Maintaining identity under oppression

docs.title: Dark Pride: Inverted Trans Flag
docs.text: The color palette inverts traditional pride colors, representing:

docs.title: Strategic Invisibility
docs.text:
• Stealth Mode: Operating in hostile environments
  • Coded Signals: Visible to community, invisible to oppressors
  • Protection: Safety through selective visibility

docs.title: Color Meanings
docs.text:
Orange (#FF6B35) - Inverted Light Blue - Warmth in cold digital spaces - Energy and action replacing passive acceptance - The fire of revolution

Teal (#00CFC1) - Inverted Pink - Technology reclaimed for healing - Clarity of purpose - Cool resistance to hot oppression

Black (#0A0E27) - Inverted White - The void from which we create - Mystery and protection - Power reclaimed from fear

Magenta (#FF00FF) - The Glitch - Errors in their system - Beauty in malfunction - The undefined and uncontainable

docs.title: Sharp Edges: No Compromise
docs.text:
The rejection of rounded corners represents:

  • Direct Action: No soft approaches to hard problems
  • Clear Boundaries: Defined spaces for safety
  • Cutting Through: Sharp tools for breaking barriers
  • Honest Aesthetics: What you see is what you get

docs.title: High Contrast: Clear Vision
docs.text:
Strong contrast ratios symbolize:

  • Binary Rejection: No grey areas in our liberation
  • Clarity: Clear communication in struggle
  • Accessibility: No one left behind
  • Bold Statements: Impossible to ignore

docs.title: Terminal Aesthetic: Reclaimed Space
docs.text:
Command-line inspired design represents:

  • Root Access: Taking control of our systems
  • Text Power: Words as weapons and shields
  • Hacker Heritage: Honoring our digital ancestors
  • Democratic Tech: Power to those who can type

docs.title: Glitch Effects: System Errors
docs.text:
Animation and distortion effects symbolize:

  • Breaking Binary: Gender, code, and society
  • Beautiful Malfunction: Finding art in errors
  • System Resistance: We are the bug, not the feature
  • Transformation: Constant change and evolution

docs.title: Media Inspirations
docs.text:
Ghost in the Shell - Questions of identity and consciousness - Cybernetic enhancement as trans metaphor - Resistance against corporate control

The Matrix - Red pill as awakening to systemic oppression - Digital resistance against machine control - Chosen family of rebels

Cyberpunk 2077 - Body modification as self-expression - Corporate dystopia as current reality - Street culture versus corporate culture

The Mandalorian - Found family structures - Honor through protection of vulnerable - Cultural preservation under empire

docs.title: Historical References
docs.text:
ACT UP Graphics - Bold, high-contrast design - Direct action aesthetics - "Silence = Death" visual language

Hacker Manifestos - Information liberation philosophy - Technological democratization - Subversive use of corporate tools

Trans Liberation Movements - Street activism aesthetics - Community care networks - Survival as resistance

docs.title: Design Decisions as Political Acts
docs.text:
Every CSS rule is a political statement:

/* Rejection of corporate softness */
border-radius: 0 !important;

/* Visibility for our community */
.security-l2::before { content: "🔴 L2 - CADRE ⚠"; }

/* Power in simplicity */
font-family: 'Impact', sans-serif;

docs.title: Accessibility as Revolution
docs.text:
Making our tools accessible is revolutionary praxis:

  • Screen Reader Support: Technology for all abilities
  • High Contrast: Visibility for all users
  • Keyboard Navigation: Multiple paths to power
  • Reduced Motion: Respecting neurological diversity

docs.title: Open Source as Mutual Aid
docs.text:
Sharing our theme freely embodies:

  • Collective Ownership: Tools belong to community
  • Knowledge Sharing: Teaching as resistance
  • Iterative Improvement: Building on each other's work
  • Documentation: Making knowledge accessible

docs.title: Evolution and Adaptation
docs.text:
The theme should evolve with the community:

  • Responsive to Feedback: Community voices matter
  • Cultural Sensitivity: Respecting diverse experiences
  • Continuous Learning: Growing with understanding
  • Fork-Friendly: Encouraging remixes and adaptations

docs.title: Ethical Considerations
docs.text:
Using this theme comes with responsibilities:

  1. Respect Origins: Honor trans hacker culture
  2. Include Everyone: Maintain accessibility
  3. Share Freely: Keep it open source
  4. Document Changes: Explain your modifications
  5. Support Community: Contribute back improvements

docs.title: Conclusion: This Is The Way

The Queer Mandalorian theme is more than aesthetics—it's a visual manifesto. It declares that:

  • We exist in digital spaces
  • We refuse to be erased or softened
  • We build tools for our liberation
  • We care for our community

Every implementation is an act of resistance. Every fork is solidarity. Every contribution is mutual aid.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This guide walks you through implementing the Queer Mandalorian theme in your DRUIDS documentation system. The theme transforms the standard MkDocs Material appearance into a revolutionary cyberpunk guerilla aesthetic.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Working DRUIDS documentation system
  • MkDocs Material theme installed
  • Basic understanding of CSS
  • Access to modify mkdocs.yml

docs.title: Step 1: Create File Structure
docs.text:
Create the following directory structure in your docs folder:

docs/
├── stylesheets/
│   ├── qm-overrides.css      # Material theme overrides
│   ├── queer-mandalorian.css # Main theme file
│   ├── qm-syntax.css         # Syntax highlighting
│   └── qm-components.css     # Component styling

docs.title: Step 2: Update MkDocs Configuration
docs.text:
Add the theme CSS files to your mkdocs.yml:

# mkdocs.yml
extra_css:
  - stylesheets/qm-overrides.css    # Load first
  - stylesheets/queer-mandalorian.css
  - stylesheets/qm-syntax.css
  - stylesheets/qm-components.css

Important: Order matters! qm-overrides.css must load first to properly override Material defaults.

docs.title: Step 3: Critical Overrides
docs.text:
The qm-overrides.css file handles Material-specific overrides:

/* Example structure for qm-overrides.css */
/* Navigation overrides */
.md-nav { /* styles */ }

/* Header overrides */
.md-header { /* styles */ }

/* Content overrides */
.md-content { /* styles */ }

docs.title: Navigation Enhancement
docs.text:
The navigation should reflect the cyberpunk aesthetic:

  • Uppercase text with letter spacing
  • Cyan hover effects with translateX animation
  • Orange active states with arrow indicators
  • Sharp edges (no border radius)

docs.title: Code Block Styling
docs.text:
Terminal-inspired code blocks require:

  • Transparent backgrounds with cyan borders
  • Terminal prompt ($) prefixes
  • Monospace fonts (JetBrains Mono preferred)
  • Syntax highlighting in theme colors

docs.title: Security Indicators
docs.text:
Implement three-tier visual security:

  • L0 (Public): Green with gradient background
  • L1 (Member): Orange with gradient background
  • L2 (Cadre): Pink/Red with warning icon

docs.title: Step 5: Typography Configuration
docs.text:
Configure the typography system:

  1. Headers: Impact or Arial Black, uppercase
  2. Body: Inter or system fonts, 19px base
  3. Code: JetBrains Mono or Fira Code
  4. Line Height: 1.75 for readability

docs.title: Step 6: Color Implementation
docs.text:
Apply the Dark Pride color palette consistently:

Primary Orange: #FF6B35 (inverted blue)
Rust: #B84A14 (H1 headers)
Cyan: #00D9FF (bright accents)
Dark Blue: #0A1628 (backgrounds)
Purple: #BD10E0 (accents)
Pink: #FF006E (warnings)
Teal: #00CFC1 (inverted pink)
Magenta: #FF00FF (glitch effects)

docs.title: Step 8: Performance Optimization
docs.text:
1. Minimize Animations: Keep glitch effects subtle
  2. Optimize Fonts: Use system fonts as fallbacks
  3. Reduce Repaints: Use transforms over position changes
  4. Lazy Load: Heavy effects only on interaction

docs.title: Step 9: Documentation
docs.text:
Document your implementation:

  1. Color choices and rationale
  2. Component modifications
  3. Accessibility decisions
  4. Browser-specific fixes

docs.title: 1. Green-on-Green Contrast
docs.text: Problem: Poor readability with similar colors Solution: Always use complementary colors (orange/blue, purple/yellow)

docs.title: 2. Excessive Border Radius
docs.text:
Problem: Material's rounded corners persist Solution: Use !important sparingly but effectively:

* { border-radius: 0 !important; }
/* Allow specific exceptions */

docs.title: 3. Code Block Readability
docs.text: Problem: Solid backgrounds too harsh Solution: Use transparent backgrounds (0.2-0.3 opacity)

docs.title: 4. Navigation Hover States
docs.text: Problem: Hover effects not visible Solution: Combine color change with transform

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This guide addresses common issues encountered when implementing the Queer Mandalorian theme and provides tested solutions based on real-world implementations.

docs.title: Green-on-Green Contrast Problems
docs.text:
Symptom: Poor readability when similar colors overlap, especially in code blocks or highlighted sections.

Solution: 

/* Use complementary colors instead */
.highlight {
  background: rgba(10, 22, 40, 0.3); /* Dark transparent */
  color: var(--qm-cyan);             /* Bright cyan text */
}

/* Avoid */
.bad-example {
  background: #00FF41;
  color: #00D9FF; /* Too similar in brightness */
}

Best Practice: Always test color combinations with a contrast checker.

docs.title: Rounded Corners Persisting
docs.text:
Symptom: Material Design's rounded corners appear despite overrides.

Root Cause: CSS specificity issues or late-loading Material styles.

Solution: 

/* Force sharp edges with high specificity */
.md-typeset *,
.md-nav *,
.md-header * {
  border-radius: 0 !important;
}

/* Allow specific exceptions */
.md-tag,
.pill,
.badge {
  border-radius: 4px !important;
}

docs.title: Excessive Negative Space
docs.text:
Symptom: Large padding makes content feel disconnected and wastes screen space.

Solution: 

/* Tighten spacing */
.md-typeset {
  line-height: 1.75; /* Instead of 2+ */
}

.md-content__inner {
  padding: 1rem 2rem; /* Reduced from defaults */
}

/* Increase font sizes proportionally */
.md-typeset {
  font-size: 1.1875rem; /* 19px base */
}

docs.title: Icon Contrast in Dark Theme
docs.text:
Symptom: Dark icons disappear on dark backgrounds.

Solution: 

/* Add glow effects for visibility */
.md-icon {
  filter: drop-shadow(0 0 2px var(--qm-cyan));
}

/* Or use bright colors */
.icon-class {
  color: var(--qm-primary-orange);
  opacity: 0.9;
}

docs.title: Code Highlighting Too Harsh
docs.text:
Symptom: Solid background colors in code blocks are jarring.

Solution: 

/* Use transparent gradients */
.highlight {
  background: linear-gradient(
    90deg,
    rgba(10, 22, 40, 0.3) 0%,
    rgba(10, 22, 40, 0.2) 100%
  );
}

/* Syntax colors with reduced opacity */
.highlight .k { /* Keywords */
  color: rgba(255, 107, 53, 0.9);
}

docs.title: Orange Navigation Bar Text Visibility
docs.text:
Symptom: White text on orange background is unreadable.

Solution: 

.md-tabs__link {
  color: #2C3E50 !important; /* Dark gray instead of white */
}

.md-tabs__link:hover {
  color: var(--qm-cyan) !important;
}

docs.title: Active Navigation State Not Clear
docs.text:
Symptom: Users can't tell which page they're on.

Solution: 

.md-nav__link--active {
  color: var(--qm-primary-orange);
  font-weight: 700;
  position: relative;
}

.md-nav__link--active::before {
  content: "▶";
  position: absolute;
  left: -1.5rem;
  color: var(--qm-magenta-glow);
}

docs.title: Mermaid Diagrams Background
docs.text:
Symptom: Mermaid diagrams have white backgrounds that clash with dark theme.

Solution: 

.mermaid {
  background: transparent !important;
}

.mermaid * {
  fill: var(--qm-text-primary) !important;
  stroke: var(--qm-cyan) !important;
}

docs.title: Table Readability
docs.text:
Symptom: Tables blend into background or have poor contrast.

Solution: 

.md-typeset table {
  border: 1px solid var(--qm-cyan);
}

.md-typeset table th {
  background: var(--qm-dark-blue);
  color: var(--qm-primary-orange);
  font-weight: 700;
}

.md-typeset table tr:hover {
  background: rgba(0, 217, 255, 0.1);
}

docs.title: Security Indicators Overlapping
docs.text:
Symptom: Security level badges overlap with content.

Solution: 

.security-l0,
.security-l1,
.security-l2 {
  position: relative;
  padding-right: 8rem; /* Space for badge */
}

.security-l2::before {
  position: absolute;
  right: 0.5rem;
  top: 0.5rem;
}

docs.title: Glitch Effects Causing Lag
docs.text:
Symptom: Page stutters when hovering over headers.

Solution: 

/* Use GPU acceleration */
@keyframes glitch {
  0% { transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0); }
  /* ... */
}

/* Reduce animation frequency */
h1:hover {
  animation: glitch 0.3s ease-in-out;
  animation-iteration-count: 1; /* Run once */
}

docs.title: Large CSS File Size
docs.text:
Symptom: Theme CSS is too large, causing slow loads.

Solution: 1. Split CSS into component files 2. Use CSS custom properties to reduce repetition 3. Minify production CSS 4. Remove unused styles

docs.title: Firefox Gradient Rendering
docs.text:
Symptom: Gradients appear banded in Firefox.

Solution: 

/* Add more color stops */
background: linear-gradient(
  90deg,
  rgba(255, 107, 53, 0.1) 0%,
  rgba(255, 107, 53, 0.08) 25%,
  rgba(255, 107, 53, 0.05) 50%,
  rgba(255, 107, 53, 0.02) 75%,
  transparent 100%
);

docs.title: Safari Focus Outline
docs.text:
Symptom: Focus outlines don't appear in Safari.

Solution: 

/* Force webkit focus */
*:focus {
  outline: 2px solid var(--qm-cyan) !important;
  outline-offset: 2px !important;
  -webkit-appearance: none;
}

docs.title: Touch Targets Too Small
docs.text:
Symptom: Links and buttons hard to tap on mobile.

Solution: 

@media (max-width: 768px) {
  .md-nav__link {
    padding: 1rem; /* Increase from 0.5rem */
    min-height: 44px; /* iOS minimum */
  }
}

docs.title: Horizontal Scroll
docs.text:
Symptom: Page scrolls horizontally on mobile.

Solution: 

/* Prevent overflow */
body {
  overflow-x: hidden;
}

/* Check for absolute positioned elements */
.problem-element {
  position: relative; /* Change from absolute */
  width: 100%; /* Constrain width */
}

docs.title: Visual Debugging
docs.text:
Add debug mode to see element boundaries:

.qm-debug * {
  outline: 1px solid magenta !important;
}

.qm-debug *::before,
.qm-debug *::after {
  outline: 1px solid cyan !important;
}

docs.title: CSS Variable Inspection
docs.text:
Check if variables are loading:

// In browser console
getComputedStyle(document.documentElement)
  .getPropertyValue('--qm-primary-orange');

docs.title: Specificity Calculator
docs.text:
When overrides aren't working:

  1. Use browser inspector to see applied styles
  2. Check specificity score
  3. Increase specificity or use !important sparingly

docs.title: Testing Checklist
docs.text:
Before deploying, verify:

  • All text meets contrast requirements
  • Navigation states are clear
  • Code blocks are readable
  • Tables have proper borders
  • Security indicators don't overlap
  • Mobile experience is usable
  • Animations respect reduced motion
  • Focus states are visible
  • No horizontal scroll on mobile
  • Page loads under 3 seconds

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you encounter issues not covered here:

  1. Check browser console for CSS errors
  2. Validate CSS with online tools
  3. Test in multiple browsers
  4. Create minimal reproduction
  5. Document with screenshots
  6. Share in community forums

"Every bug is a learning opportunity. Every fix makes the revolution stronger." - Trans Hacker Collective

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Queer Mandalorian theme represents a revolutionary fusion of cyberpunk guerilla aesthetics with trans hacker culture, expressed through inverted pride colors and sharp, uncompromising design elements. This theme embodies resistance, chosen family, and the subversive use of technology for liberation.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Add to mkdocs.yml
extra_css:
  - stylesheets/qm-overrides.css
  - stylesheets/queer-mandalorian.css
  - stylesheets/qm-syntax.css
  - stylesheets/qm-components.css

docs.title: Core Concepts
docs.text:
1. Guerilla Warrior - Resourceful, rebellious, fighting from the margins
  2. Cyberpunk Aesthetic - High-tech rebellion against corporate control
  3. Trans Hacker Culture - Subversive use of technology for liberation
  4. Dark Pride - Inverted pride colors representing resistance

docs.title: Visual Language
docs.text:
• Sharp edges: No compromise, direct action (0-4px border radius max)
  • High contrast: Clear boundaries, no ambiguity
  • Terminal aesthetic: Reclaiming tech spaces with monospace fonts
  • Glitch effects: Breaking binary systems through CSS animations

docs.title: Dark Pride Palette (Inverted Trans Colors)
docs.text:
:root {
  /* Primary Colors */
  --qm-primary-orange: #FF6B35;    /* Inverted light blue */
  --qm-rust: #B84A14;              /* H1 headers */
  --qm-cyan: #00D9FF;              /* Bright accent */
  --qm-dark-blue: #0A1628;         /* Headers/code blocks */

  /* Accent Colors */
  --qm-purple: #BD10E0;            /* Bright accent */
  --qm-pink: #FF006E;              /* Hot pink accent */
  --qm-teal: #00CFC1;              /* Inverted pink */
  --qm-magenta-glow: #FF00FF;      /* Glitch effects */

  /* Background Colors */
  --qm-bg-primary: #0A0E27;        /* Deep space black */
  --qm-bg-code: rgba(10, 22, 40, 0.8);  /* Transparent code */

  /* Text Colors */
  --qm-text-primary: #E0E0E0;      /* Main text */
  --qm-text-bright: #FFFFFF;       /* Headers */
  --qm-text-muted: #B0B0B0;        /* Secondary text */
}

docs.title: Color Symbolism
docs.text:
• Orange (inverted blue): Warmth and energy replacing coolness
  • Teal (inverted pink): Technology and clarity
  • Black (inverted white): Power and mystery
  • Magenta accents: The glow of resistance

docs.title: Font Stack
docs.text:
/* Headers - Heavy and impactful */
--qm-font-headers: 'Impact', 'Arial Black', sans-serif;

/* Body - Clean and readable */
--qm-font-body: 'Inter', -apple-system, sans-serif;

/* Code - Terminal aesthetic */
--qm-font-mono: 'JetBrains Mono', 'Fira Code', monospace;

docs.title: Typography Scale
docs.text:
/* Base: 19px with 1.75 line height */
--qm-text-base: 1.1875rem;
--qm-line-height: 1.75;

/* Headers */
--qm-h1: 3rem;        /* 48px */
--qm-h2: 2.25rem;     /* 36px */
--qm-h3: 1.75rem;     /* 28px */
--qm-h4: 1.375rem;    /* 22px */

/* Letter spacing */
--qm-letter-spacing-wide: 4px;   /* H1 headers */
--qm-letter-spacing-normal: 2px; /* H2-H3 headers */

docs.title: Security Indicators
docs.text:
Visual security classification with both color and pattern:

/* L0 - Public (Green) */
.security-l0 {
  border-left: 4px solid #00FF41;
  background: linear-gradient(90deg, rgba(0,255,65,0.1) 0%, transparent 100%);
}

/* L1 - Member (Orange) */
.security-l1 {
  border-left: 4px solid #FF6B35;
  background: linear-gradient(90deg, rgba(255,107,53,0.1) 0%, transparent 100%);
}

/* L2 - Cadre (Red) */
.security-l2 {
  border-left: 4px solid #FF006E;
  background: linear-gradient(90deg, rgba(255,0,110,0.1) 0%, transparent 100%);
  position: relative;
}

.security-l2::before {
  content: "⚠";
  position: absolute;
  right: 0.5rem;
  top: 0.5rem;
  color: #FF006E;
}

docs.title: Code Blocks
docs.text:
Terminal-inspired transparent backgrounds:

.highlight {
  background: rgba(10, 22, 40, 0.3) !important;
  border: 1px solid var(--qm-cyan);
  border-radius: 0;
  position: relative;
}

.highlight::before {
  content: "$ ";
  color: var(--qm-cyan);
  position: absolute;
  left: 1rem;
  top: 1rem;
  font-family: var(--qm-font-mono);
}

docs.title: Glitch Effects
docs.text:
CSS animations for headers:

@keyframes glitch {
  0%, 100% { text-shadow: 2px 2px 0 var(--qm-cyan), -2px -2px 0 var(--qm-magenta-glow); }
  25% { text-shadow: -2px 2px 0 var(--qm-cyan), 2px -2px 0 var(--qm-magenta-glow); }
  50% { text-shadow: 2px -2px 0 var(--qm-cyan), -2px 2px 0 var(--qm-magenta-glow); }
  75% { text-shadow: -2px -2px 0 var(--qm-cyan), 2px 2px 0 var(--qm-magenta-glow); }
}

h1:hover {
  animation: glitch 0.3s ease-in-out;
}

docs.title: Step 1: File Structure
docs.text:
docs/stylesheets/
├── qm-overrides.css      # Material theme overrides
├── queer-mandalorian.css # Main theme file
├── qm-syntax.css         # Syntax highlighting
└── qm-components.css     # Component styling

docs.title: Step 2: Critical Overrides
docs.text:
Remove Material Design softness:

/* Sharp edges everywhere */
* {
  border-radius: 0 !important;
}

/* Exception for pills/badges */
.md-tag, .pill {
  border-radius: 4px !important;
}

docs.title: Step 3: Navigation Enhancement
docs.text:
.md-nav__link {
  color: var(--qm-text-primary);
  transition: all 0.2s ease;
  position: relative;
  text-transform: uppercase;
  letter-spacing: 1px;
}

.md-nav__link:hover {
  color: var(--qm-cyan);
  background: rgba(0, 217, 255, 0.1);
  transform: translateX(4px);
}

.md-nav__link--active {
  color: var(--qm-primary-orange);
  font-weight: 700;
}

.md-nav__link--active::before {
  content: "▶";
  position: absolute;
  left: -1.5rem;
  color: var(--qm-magenta-glow);
}

docs.title: Contrast Requirements
docs.text:
All color combinations meet WCAG 2.1 standards:

  • Normal text: 4.5:1 minimum
  • Large text: 3:1 minimum
  • Interactive elements: Clear focus indicators

docs.title: Motion Sensitivity
docs.text:
@media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce) {
  * {
    animation-duration: 0.01ms !important;
    animation-iteration-count: 1 !important;
    transition-duration: 0.01ms !important;
  }
}

docs.title: Screen Reader Support
docs.text:
• Semantic HTML structure maintained
  • Security levels announced via aria-labels
  • Skip navigation links preserved

docs.title: Aesthetic References
docs.text:
1. Mandalorian: Chosen family, honor through action, warrior code
  2. Queer: Rejecting normativity, celebrating difference, found family
  3. Hacker: Information wants to be free, technology as liberation
  4. Revolutionary: Building new worlds, collective action

docs.title: Design Inspiration
docs.text:
• Ghost in the Shell UI elements
  • The Matrix terminal aesthetics
  • Cyberpunk 2077 color palettes
  • Trans flag inverted for stealth mode
  • ACT UP graphic design principles

docs.title: Visual Testing
docs.text:
Create test pages for all components:

# Test pages to create
docs/test-qm-typography.md
docs/test-qm-components.md  
docs/test-qm-code.md
docs/test-qm-tables.md

docs.title: Accessibility Testing

pa11y http://localhost:8000 --reporter cli

# Screen reader testing

docs.title: Browser Support
docs.text:
• Chrome/Edge 90+
  • Firefox 88+
  • Safari 14+
  • Mobile browsers

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
1. Green-on-green contrast: Use complementary colors (orange/blue)
  2. Rounded corners appearing: Check cascade order of CSS files
  3. Low contrast in code blocks: Adjust transparent backgrounds
  4. Glitch effects too intense: Reduce animation duration

docs.title: Debug Mode
docs.text:
Add class to body for debugging:

<body class="qm-debug">

.qm-debug * {
  outline: 1px solid magenta !important;
}

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
When contributing to the Queer Mandalorian theme:

  1. Respect the cultural significance
  2. Maintain accessibility standards
  3. Test on multiple devices
  4. Document color choices
  5. Include screenshots of changes

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The DRUIDS Security Theme provides visual indicators throughout Obsidian to help users quickly identify the security classification of documents. This theme uses color coding to distinguish between L0 (Public), L1 (Member), and L2 (Cadre) content.

docs.title: Security Level Colors
docs.text:
• L0 - Public: 🟢 Green (#22c55e)
  • Safe for public consumption

  • No restrictions on sharing

  • L1 - Member: 🟡 Yellow/Amber (#f59e0b)

  • Member-only content

  • Requires membership verification

  • L2 - Cadre: 🔴 Red (#ef4444)

  • Highly sensitive content
  • Encrypted, cadre access only

docs.title: 1. File Explorer
docs.text:
• File and folder names are colored based on their vault location
  • /public/ paths show in green
  • /member/ paths show in yellow
  • /cadre/ paths show in red
  • Encrypted files (.gpg) show with a lock icon 🔒

docs.title: 2. Document Headers
docs.text:
• First heading displays a security badge
  • Badge shows security level and classification
  • Automatically derived from frontmatter security_level

docs.title: 3. Editor Indicators
docs.text:
• Left border shows security color in frontmatter
  • Helps identify security level while editing

docs.title: 4. Tabs
docs.text:
• Active tab has colored bottom border
  • Quick visual reference for open documents

docs.title: 5. Tags
docs.text:
• Security tags have colored backgrounds
  • #security/L0 - green background
  • #security/L1 - yellow background
  • #security/L2 - red background

docs.title: 6. Graph View
docs.text:
• Nodes colored by security classification
  • Enables security-aware navigation
  • Visual clustering by security level

docs.title: 7. Search Results
docs.text:
• Results have colored left borders
  • Quickly identify security level in search

docs.title: 8. Quick Switcher
docs.text:
• Files prefixed with colored emoji
  • 🟢 for public files
  • 🟡 for member files
  • 🔴 for cadre files

docs.title: 9. Kanban Cards
docs.text:
• Cards with security markers get colored borders
  • Background tint matches security level

docs.title: 1. Enable the CSS Snippet
docs.text:
1. Copy druids-security-theme.css to your vault's .obsidian/snippets/ folder
  2. Go to Settings → Appearance → CSS snippets
  3. Enable "druids-security-theme"
  4. Reload Obsidian if needed

docs.title: 2. Configure Style Settings
docs.text:
1. Ensure Style Settings plugin is installed
  2. Go to Settings → Style Settings
  3. Find "DRUIDS Security Theme" section
  4. Customize colors if needed
  5. Toggle visual indicators on/off

docs.title: 3. Apply to All Vaults
docs.text: The theme is in the shared configuration, so it will automatically apply to all vaults through the symlink system.

docs.title: Changing Colors
docs.text:
In Style Settings, you can customize:

  • L0 Public Color
  • L1 Member Color
  • L2 Cadre Color

docs.title: Toggling Features
docs.text:
You can enable/disable:

  • File badges
  • Tab indicators
  • Graph node coloring

docs.title: Custom CSS
docs.text:
To add your own security styling, create a new snippet:

/* Custom security styling */
.my-custom-class {
  /* Your styles here */
}

docs.title: DO's
docs.text:
• ✅ Keep color associations consistent
  • ✅ Use theme to verify security levels
  • ✅ Report any missing indicators
  • ✅ Customize colors for accessibility
  • ✅ Test theme in both light/dark modes

docs.title: DON'Ts
docs.text:
• ❌ Rely solely on colors for security
  • ❌ Disable security indicators
  • ❌ Use similar colors for different levels
  • ❌ Ignore visual warnings
  • ❌ Share screenshots with L2 indicators

docs.title: Color Blind Considerations
docs.text:
The default colors are distinguishable for most color vision deficiencies. However, you can:

  1. Adjust colors in Style Settings
  2. Use patterns instead of colors
  3. Enable additional text indicators

docs.title: High Contrast Mode
docs.text:
For better visibility:

/* Add to custom CSS */
.theme-dark {
  --druids-l0-color: #00ff00;
  --druids-l1-color: #ffff00;
  --druids-l2-color: #ff0000;
}

docs.title: Indicators Not Showing
docs.text:
1. Check CSS snippet is enabled
  2. Verify Style Settings configuration
  3. Reload Obsidian
  4. Check for CSS conflicts

docs.title: Wrong Colors
docs.text:
1. Verify frontmatter security_level
  2. Check file location matches security
  3. Clear Obsidian cache
  4. Disable conflicting themes

docs.title: Performance Issues
docs.text:
1. Disable complex selectors
  2. Reduce animation effects
  3. Limit active indicators

docs.title: Integration with Fort Knox
docs.text:
The security theme works alongside the Fort Knox plugin:

  • Fort Knox enforces security rules
  • Theme provides visual feedback
  • Together they create defense in depth

docs.title: Future Enhancements
docs.text:
Planned features:

  • Animation for security violations
  • Hover tooltips with security info
  • Security level in status bar
  • Automated security reports
  • Mobile-specific indicators

docs.title: Support
docs.text:
For issues or suggestions:

  1. Check existing CSS snippets
  2. Review Style Settings
  3. Report bugs in DRUIDS repository
  4. Suggest enhancements via proposals

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The DRUIDS security visual coding system provides immediate visual recognition of content security levels across all interfaces. This system uses multiple sensory channels to ensure security awareness is maintained at all times.

docs.title: L0 - Public (Blue)
docs.text:
• Purpose: Content freely available to everyone
  • Color: #3B82F6 (Accessible Blue)
  • Icon: 🟢 or 🌐
  • Use Cases: Educational materials, public statements, recruitment content

docs.title: L1 - Member (Amber/Gold)
docs.text:
• Purpose: Internal content for verified members
  • Color: #D6AA00 (Comrade Gold)
  • Icon: 🟡 or 🔒
  • Use Cases: Meeting notes, development docs, member resources

docs.title: L2 - Cadre (Red)
docs.text:
• Purpose: Highly restricted operational content
  • Color: #CC3C3A (Revolutionary Red)
  • Icon: 🔴 or ⚠️
  • Use Cases: Strategic planning, sensitive operations

docs.title: Base Security Classes
docs.text:
/* Base security indicator */
.security-indicator {
  position: relative;
  padding-left: var(--druids-space-lg);
}

.security-indicator::before {
  content: '';
  position: absolute;
  left: 0;
  top: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  width: var(--druids-border-width-heavy);
}

/* L0 - Public */
.security-l0,
.security-indicator.security-l0 {
  background-color: var(--druids-security-l0-bg);
  border-left: var(--druids-border-width-heavy) solid var(--druids-security-l0-border);
}

.security-l0::before {
  background-color: var(--druids-security-l0-border);
}

/* L1 - Member */
.security-l1,
.security-indicator.security-l1 {
  background-color: var(--druids-security-l1-bg);
  border-left: var(--druids-border-width-heavy) solid var(--druids-security-l1-border);
}

.security-l1::before {
  background-color: var(--druids-security-l1-border);
}

/* L2 - Cadre */
.security-l2,
.security-indicator.security-l2 {
  background-color: var(--druids-security-l2-bg);
  border-left: var(--druids-border-width-heavy) solid var(--druids-security-l2-border);
}

.security-l2::before {
  background-color: var(--druids-security-l2-border);
}

docs.title: Security Badges
docs.text:
/* Badge styles */
.security-badge {
  display: inline-flex;
  align-items: center;
  padding: var(--druids-space-xs) var(--druids-space-sm);
  border-radius: var(--druids-border-radius-sm);
  font-size: var(--druids-font-size-xs);
  font-weight: var(--font-weight-semibold);
  text-transform: uppercase;
  letter-spacing: var(--letter-spacing-wide);
}

.security-badge-l0 {
  color: var(--druids-security-l0-text);
  background-color: var(--druids-security-l0-bg);
  border: 1px solid var(--druids-security-l0-border);
}

.security-badge-l1 {
  color: var(--druids-security-l1-text);
  background-color: var(--druids-security-l1-bg);
  border: 1px solid var(--druids-security-l1-border);
}

.security-badge-l2 {
  color: var(--druids-security-l2-text);
  background-color: var(--druids-security-l2-bg);
  border: 1px solid var(--druids-security-l2-border);
}

/* Icon variant */
.security-badge::before {
  content: attr(data-icon);
  margin-right: var(--druids-space-xs);
}

.security-badge-l0::before { content: "🟢"; }
.security-badge-l1::before { content: "🟡"; }
.security-badge-l2::before { content: "🔴"; }

docs.title: File Explorer
docs.text:
/* Color-code files by vault */
.nav-file-title[data-path*="public"] {
  color: var(--druids-security-l0-color);
}

.nav-file-title[data-path*="member"] {
  color: var(--druids-security-l1-color);
}

.nav-file-title[data-path*="cadre"] {
  color: var(--druids-security-l2-color);
}

/* Folder icons */
.nav-folder-title[data-path*="public"]::before {
  content: "🟢 ";
}

.nav-folder-title[data-path*="member"]::before {
  content: "🟡 ";
}

.nav-folder-title[data-path*="cadre"]::before {
  content: "🔴 ";
}

docs.title: Editor View
docs.text:
/* Security indicator in editor */
.workspace-leaf.mod-active .view-content {
  position: relative;
}

.workspace-leaf.mod-active[data-security="l0"] .view-content {
  border-left: 4px solid var(--druids-security-l0-border);
}

.workspace-leaf.mod-active[data-security="l1"] .view-content {
  border-left: 4px solid var(--druids-security-l1-border);
}

.workspace-leaf.mod-active[data-security="l2"] .view-content {
  border-left: 4px solid var(--druids-security-l2-border);
}

docs.title: Graph View
docs.text:
/* Node colors by security level */
.graph-node[data-security="l0"] {
  fill: var(--druids-security-l0-color);
  stroke: var(--druids-security-l0-border);
}

.graph-node[data-security="l1"] {
  fill: var(--druids-security-l1-color);
  stroke: var(--druids-security-l1-border);

.graph-node[data-security="l2"] {

docs.title: JavaScript Enhancement
docs.text:
// Security level detection
class SecurityVisualizer {
  constructor() {
    this.levels = {
      public: { level: 0, class: 'security-l0', icon: '🟢' },
      member: { level: 1, class: 'security-l1', icon: '🟡' },
      cadre: { level: 2, class: 'security-l2', icon: '🔴' }
    };
  }

  // Apply security visualization to element
  applySecurityLevel(element, level) {
    const security = this.levels[level];
    if (!security) return;

    element.classList.add(security.class);
    element.setAttribute('data-security', `l${security.level}`);
    element.setAttribute('aria-label', `Security Level ${security.level}: ${level}`);
  }

  // Auto-detect from file path
  detectFromPath(path) {
    if (path.includes('/public/')) return 'public';
    if (path.includes('/member/')) return 'member';
    if (path.includes('/cadre/')) return 'cadre';
    return 'public'; // Default to lowest security
  }
}

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This guide consolidates all theme development documentation for DRUIDS, with accessibility as the primary focus. Every theme must prioritize disability justice and inclusive design while maintaining revolutionary aesthetics.

docs.title: Accessibility First
docs.text:
1. Disability Justice: Our revolution must be accessible to all comrades
  2. WCAG 2.1 AA Compliance: Minimum standard for all themes
  3. Progressive Enhancement: Core functionality without CSS/JS
  4. Multiple Indicators: Never rely solely on color for information

docs.title: Revolutionary Aesthetics
docs.text:
1. Anti-Oppression Design: Visual resistance to corporate aesthetics
  2. Community Identity: Themes express organizational values
  3. Security Visualization: Clear L0/L1/L2 indicators
  4. Cultural Significance: Honor revolutionary traditions

docs.title: Creating Your First Theme
docs.text:
1. Start with Accessibility 

    /* Base your theme on proven accessible foundations */
@import url('/stylesheets/accessibility-enhancements.css');

  2. Test Early and Often

npm run test:a11y
axe-devtools  # Browser extension

  3. Follow the Queer Mandalorian Example

  4. Study /stylesheets/queer-mandalorian.css for best practices
  5. Review qm-accessibility.md for detailed testing

docs.text:
All themes MUST meet these contrast ratios:

Element Type Minimum Ratio Preferred Body text 4.5:1 7:1 (AAA) Large text 3:1 4.5:1 UI components 3:1 4.5:1 Focus indicators 3:1 4.5:1

docs.title: Security Level Indicators
docs.text:
Never use color alone. Combine multiple indicators:

/* Example: L2 (Cadre) Security */
.L2 {
  /* Visual indicators */
  color: var(--l2-text);
  background: var(--l2-bg);
  border: 2px solid var(--l2-border);

  /* Pattern overlay for colorblind users */

    45deg,
    transparent,
    transparent 10px,
    rgba(255,0,0,0.1) 10px,
    rgba(255,0,0,0.1) 20px

  /* Icon indicator */

    content: "🔒";

docs.title: Step 1: Research and Planning
docs.text:
1. Understand Your Users
  2. Survey community accessibility needs
  3. Consider various disabilities (visual, motor, cognitive)

  4. Plan for assistive technology compatibility

  5. Define Visual Identity

  6. Choose colors that meet contrast requirements
  7. Select readable fonts (avoid thin weights)
  8. Design clear iconography

docs.title: Step 2: Build Accessible Foundation
docs.text:
/* Start with accessibility */
* {
  /* Ensure text is readable */
  line-height: 1.5;
  letter-spacing: 0.02em;
}

/* Focus styles */
:focus {
  outline: 3px solid var(--focus-color);
  outline-offset: 2px;
}

  position: absolute;
  top: -40px;
  left: 0;

  color: var(--text-primary);
  padding: 8px;
  z-index: 100;
  text-decoration: none;

docs.title: Step 3: Add Revolutionary Aesthetics
docs.text:
Build visual identity on top of accessible foundation:

/* Example: Cyberpunk aesthetic with accessibility */
.header {
  /* Accessible base */
  color: var(--text-primary);
  background: var(--bg-primary);

  /* Aesthetic enhancement */
  background-image: 
    linear-gradient(45deg, transparent 30%, rgba(0,217,255,0.1) 50%, transparent 70%);
  text-shadow: 0 0 20px rgba(0,217,255,0.5);

  /* Ensure contrast maintained */

docs.title: Step 4: Test Thoroughly
docs.text:
1. Automated Testing 

    # Run accessibility tests
npm run test:a11y

# Check contrast ratios
npx color-contrast-checker

  2. Manual Testing

  3. Navigate with keyboard only
  4. Test with screen readers (NVDA, JAWS, VoiceOver)
  5. Verify with browser zoom at 200%

  6. Check with Windows High Contrast mode

  7. Real User Testing

  8. Recruit testers with disabilities
  9. Gather feedback on actual usage
  10. Iterate based on findings

docs.title: Do's ✅
docs.text:
• Start with accessibility, add aesthetics after
  • Test with real assistive technologies
  • Provide multiple ways to perceive information
  • Document all accessibility features
  • Include disabled comrades in design process

docs.title: Don'ts ❌
docs.text:
• Don't use color as the only indicator
  • Don't remove focus indicators
  • Don't use fonts smaller than 14px
  • Don't create seizure-inducing animations
  • Don't assume your users' abilities

docs.title: 1. Security Indicators (security-indicators.css)
docs.text:
Implements the three-tier visual security system:

/* L0 - Public (Forest Green #228B22) */
.L0, 
[data-security="L0"],
.nav-file[data-path*="/public/"],
.tree-item[data-path*="/public/"] {
  border-left: 4px solid #228B22 !important;
  background: linear-gradient(
    45deg, 
    transparent 25%, 
    rgba(34, 139, 34, 0.05) 25%, 
    rgba(34, 139, 34, 0.05) 50%, 
    transparent 50%
  );
  background-size: 20px 20px;
}

/* L1 - Member (Saddle Brown #8B4513) */
.L1,
[data-security="L1"], 
.nav-file[data-path*="/member/"],
.tree-item[data-path*="/member/"] {
  border-left: 4px solid #8B4513 !important;
  background: repeating-linear-gradient(
    -45deg,
    transparent,
    transparent 10px,
    rgba(139, 69, 19, 0.05) 10px,
    rgba(139, 69, 19, 0.05) 20px
  );
}

/* L2 - Cadre (Sienna #A0522D) */
.L2,
[data-security="L2"],
.nav-file[data-path*="/cadre/"],
.tree-item[data-path*="/cadre/"] {
  border-left: 4px solid #A0522D !important;
  background: repeating-linear-gradient(
    45deg,
    transparent,
    transparent 10px,
    rgba(160, 82, 45, 0.05) 10px,
    rgba(160, 82, 45, 0.05) 20px
  ),
  repeating-linear-gradient(
    -45deg,
    transparent,
    transparent 10px,
    rgba(160, 82, 45, 0.05) 10px,
    rgba(160, 82, 45, 0.05) 20px
  );

Revolutionary aesthetic theme:

/* Color Variables */
body.theme-dark {

  --druids-secondary: #8B4513;      /* Saddle brown */

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Traditional test-driven development (TDD) often perpetuates ableism by centering non-disabled experiences and prioritizing compliance over actual usability. This framework reimagines testing through a disability justice lens—where tests become tools for liberation rather than checkboxes for compliance.

docs.title: 1. Nothing About Us Without Us
docs.text:
Testing must be done WITH disabled communities, not FOR them:

// ❌ Paternalistic Approach
test('form has ARIA labels', () => {
  expect(form.querySelector('[aria-label]')).toBeTruthy();
});

// ✅ Community-Centered Approach
test('form is understandable via screen reader', async () => {
  const tester = await getCommunitytester('screen-reader-user');
  const result = await tester.evaluateForm(form);
  expect(result.canUnderstandPurpose).toBe(true);
  expect(result.canCompleteTask).toBe(true);
});

docs.title: 2. Outcome Over Compliance
docs.text:
Measure whether disabled users can accomplish tasks, not whether code meets specifications:

describe('Task Completion Testing', () => {
  test('users with motor disabilities can submit timesheet', async () => {
    const user = createTestUser({ 
      disability: 'motor',
      assistiveTech: 'speech-recognition' 
    });

    const result = await user.completeTask('submit-timesheet');

    expect(result.completed).toBe(true);
    expect(result.painPoints).toHaveLength(0);
    expect(result.timeToComplete).toBeLessThan(user.baseline * 1.5);
  });
});

docs.title: 3. Intersectional Coverage
docs.text:
Disability doesn't exist in isolation. Test for multiply-marginalized experiences:

const requiredPerspectives = [
  'blind-keyboard-user',
  'low-vision-magnification', 
  'motor-disability-speech',
  'cognitive-differences',
  'chronic-illness-fatigue',
  'deafblind-braille-user',
  'neurodivergent-sensory'
];

docs.title: Chronic Illness Accommodations
docs.text:
describe('Energy Conservation Features', () => {
  test('all forms save progress automatically', () => {
    // Accommodates fatigue, brain fog, pain flares
    const form = renderComplexForm();
    fillPartialForm(form, 30); // 30% complete

    triggerAutoSave();
    const saved = getSavedFormData();

    expect(saved.percentComplete).toBe(30);
    expect(saved.canResumeAnytime).toBe(true);
  });

  test('generous timeout warnings', () => {
    const WARNING_TIME = getSessionTimeoutWarning();

    // Brain fog needs processing time
    expect(WARNING_TIME).toBeAtLeast(5 * MINUTES);
    expect(canRequestExtension()).toBe(true);
  });
});

docs.title: Cognitive Load Management
docs.text:
describe('ADHD-Friendly Patterns', () => {
  test('focus persistence through distractions', () => {
    const element = document.activeElement;

    // Simulate notification/distraction
    triggerSystemNotification();

    // Focus shouldn't be stolen
    expect(document.activeElement).toBe(element);
    expect(getFocusIndicator(element).visible).toBe(true);
  });

  test('clear navigation hierarchy', () => {
    const hierarchy = getNavigationStructure();

    expect(hierarchy.maxDepth).toBeLessThanOrEqual(3);
    expect(hierarchy.hasCircularPaths).toBe(false);
    expect(hierarchy.breadcrumbsAlwaysVisible).toBe(true);
  });
});

docs.title: Beyond WCAG Minimums
docs.text:
describe('Real Contrast Needs', () => {
  test('contrast boost beyond AA standards', () => {
    enableUserPreference('ultra-high-contrast');

    const pairs = getAllColorPairs();
    pairs.forEach(pair => {
      const ratio = getContrastRatio(pair.foreground, pair.background);

      // WCAG AA is 4.5:1, but many need 15:1+
      expect(ratio).toBeGreaterThan(15);

      // But not pure white on black (halation)
      expect(pair).not.toBePureWhiteOnBlack();
    });
  });
});

describe('Multiple Paths to Success', () => {

    const methods = getDateInputMethods();

    expect(methods).toIncludeAll([
      'textInput',           // "2025-07-01"
      'dropdownSelects',     // Month/Day/Year dropdowns
      'calendarWidget',      // Visual calendar

docs.title: Why not just use Google Docs?
docs.text:
Would you hand over your organizations most sensitive documents to a federal agent? Probably not. Well, when you use Google Docs, that is exactly what you are doing whether or not you intend to do so! Comrade, but isn't it true that Microsoft runs GitHub? Yes, that is a true statement, but a few points to consider:

  1. Does your organization have a public website? If so, you already gave every single thing on that website to the FBI. Guaranteed, 100% of the time, every single time. And as will be discussed in our Security Theory, most of the stuff you should be doing at this point of development should be public! After all, how else are the masses supposed to find you if the only place you hang out is the dark web? But for those odd 5-10% of documents that are not public information, well - we use RSA encryption to keep them safe. Not even the feds can break into that.

docs.title: Is this too complex for small organizations?
docs.text: No! DRUIDS is designed for 5-50 person organizations. The 15-minute quick start gets you running fast, and the visual security indicators prevent mistakes. It's actually simpler than managing scattered Google Docs, Discord channels, and Signal threads.

docs.title: What about non-technical members?
docs.text:
Most DRUIDS usage requires no technical skills:

  • Creating meeting minutes is template-based
  • Security is visual (green/gold/red borders)
  • Search is just Ctrl+O
  • Everything works like a wiki

The technical setup is one-time, then everyone can contribute.

docs.title: How secure is it really?
docs.text:
DRUIDS implements real security for real threats:

  • L2 isolation protects against raids and subpoenas
  • Git distribution prevents single points of failure
  • Visual indicators prevent accidental leaks
  • Offline capability works without internet

It's not paranoia - it's protection against documented threats to organizers.

docs.title: What if someone's device is compromised?
docs.text:
The three-tier system limits damage:

  • L0 (public) exposure doesn't matter
  • L1 (member) exposure is contained
  • L2 (cadre) is isolated on separate devices/repos

Plus Git history shows exactly what was accessed when.

docs.title: What's the real time investment?
docs.text:
• 15 minutes: See value with quick start
  • 45 minutes: Full local setup
  • 2-3 days: Organization fully onboarded
  • Ongoing: 5 minutes per meeting for minutes

Compare to hours lost searching chat history or recreating lost documents.

docs.title: Can we migrate existing content?
docs.text:
Yes! The Migration Guide covers this. In a nutshell, you simply export your Google Docs into the Markdown format, and then import them into DRUIDS. Don't worry about if they're nice and tidy - we have automatic cleaning codes that will take care of all that for you!

If you can get it in a markdown file, you can get it into DRUIDS.

docs.title: What if our main organizer leaves?
docs.text:
That's exactly what DRUIDS prevents! With distributed Git repos:

  • No single person has all passwords
  • Knowledge is preserved in Git history
  • New people can onboard from documentation
  • Organization continues without disruption

docs.title: How does this help with democratic centralism?
docs.text: DRUIDS embeds democratic centralist principles into the technology. The centralism comes from having centrally enforced procedures and workflows that are transparently and equally enforced. The democracy comes from being assured by a cryptotgraphic algorithm that the decisions are made by the majority of the organization, and that the decisions are made by the people who are most knowledgeable about the issue at hand.

docs.title: Will this create more work for our secretary?
docs.text:
Actually less! DRUIDS automates:

  • Document ID generation
  • Meeting minute templates
  • Security classification
  • Task extraction from meetings
  • Searchable archives

No more maintaining multiple Google Docs or losing notes in Signal.

docs.title: How do we handle conflicts or disagreements?
docs.text:
Git's merge conflict resolution mirrors organizational conflict resolution:

  • Different views are explicitly shown
  • Must be resolved through discussion
  • Final decision is recorded
  • Can always see what changed and why

docs.title: What about organizing actions or protests?
docs.text:
L2 security tier is designed for sensitive planning:

  • Completely isolated from public/member tiers
  • Not accessible even if devices are seized
  • Visual indicators prevent accidental exposure
  • Can still coordinate without phone metadata trails

docs.title: Do we need to be online all the time?
docs.text:
No! DRUIDS works fully offline5:

  • Obsidian is a local application
  • Git repos are on your machine
  • Sync when you have internet
  • Perfect for rural organizing

docs.title: What if we're not "tech people"?
docs.text:
Most revolutionary orgs aren't! DRUIDS uses:

  • Simple markdown (like texting)
  • Visual cues instead of complex permissions
  • Templates for everything
  • Community support available

Tech knowledge helps but isn't required for daily use.

docs.title: How much does this cost?
docs.text:
Absolutely nothing except your time and attention. There are no bills or subscriptions to worry about! DRUIDS is built on free/open source tools:

  • Git: Free
  • Obsidian: Free for personal use
  • GitHub: Free for public repos
  • MkDocs: Free
  • Your time: Invaluable but well-spent

However, if you would like to support the development of DRUIDS, you can make a donation to the Cadre of KSBC who have been working on it for months, putting in countless hours of work.

docs.title: Can we customize it for our organization?
docs.text:
Yes, if you are feeling up to the task of developing your own solution, you are free to do so! As long as you keep the software open source, you credit the Kansas Socialist Book Club for developing the original copy, and you DO NOT make ANY monetary profits from it, then what you do with DRUIDS is your business.

However, if you find something not to your liking, the developers strongly encourage you to reach out and let them know what kind of improvements you had in mind. Teamwork makes the dream work, after all!

docs.title: What if Git/GitHub goes away?
docs.text:
Right now, most orgs who will consider DRUIDS are probably small, local book clubs or mutual aid societies well-versed in Marxism. Some might call our product overkill, but we prefer to call it scalability. DRUIDS is, in fact, desinged to be capable of expansion. It's also designed to be portable, and not bound to any one platform.1 Your data is never locked in for the following reasons:

  1. All content is plain text. You can literally use any word processor you want, even the ancient vi or notepad.
  2. Git, the underlying technology behind the merging capabilities, is 100% free and open source. It was invented by Linus Torvalds, the same guy who invented the Linux kernel. Git repos can move to any Git host.2
  3. We prefer you to use it on our custom image of the Tails operating system, which will eventually be conveniently packaged for you to install yourself3 on a thumb drive. However, you could operate it on any operating system4.

docs.title: Is this just for socialists?
docs.text: While we know there are certain fascists who take a keen interest in projects like DRUIDS, it' snot because they want to use it themselves! However, we suppose there is absolutely nothing stopping the Federal Bureau of Investigations4, Turning Point USA or Peter Thiel from appropriating DRUIDS for their own methods. Other than the fact that fascists are firstly often working in tech thesmselves, and two that they have boatloads more money than we do.

docs.title: Where do we start?
docs.text:
1. One person does the Quick Start (15 minutes)
  2. Show others at your next meeting
  3. Pilot with meeting minutes for a month
  4. Leave A Comment on the Giscus with any questions, issues, problems, or suggestions you have. We love comradely criticism!

Don't try to migrate everything at once.

docs.text:

docs.title: What is DRUIDS?
docs.text: Before we can answer what DRUIDS is, we should answer a more fundamental question: what do organizations actually do? Political organizations are composed of people, but they're more than the sum of the individual members. An organization is a finely-tuned cybernetic system, operated and shaped by the people within it. Therefore, an organization performs some kind of a function. And what exactly is a function? A function is fundamentally a kind of relationship that takes something as an input, transforms it, and then returns it as output which in turn is fed into the next iteration of the function. So, since organizations have some manner of function, DRUIDS can be said to be a framework for building and operating organizations that allows them to precisely define and execute their function.

docs.title: Fundamental Problems of Organizations
docs.text: In our experience, we have determined the following problems to be the most fundamental problems from which all organizations suffer in the United States. These problems are not unique to the United States, but they are particularly acute here. We want to address these problems not just by pointing themn out, but instead by providing a solution. This is our attempt to do precisely that. The six problems are:

docs.title: Political Errors
docs.text:
Organizations often hold incorrect political lines that don't correspond to material reality. They make analyses based on idealistic conceptions of the world, rather than dealing with the world as it actually exists. This is a problem because it leads to a lack of clarity about what the organization is actually doing, and it leads to a lack of clarity about what the organization is actually trying to achieve.

DRUIDS cannot determine the corrrect political line; only human beings can do that. What DRUIDS can do, however, is provide a framework for developing and refining political understanding by giving you a secure and structured way to organize your work, your documents, and your decisions. They are organized and sturctured in such a way that democratic centralism is hard-coded into the very technological structure of DRUIDS.

DRUIDS has a focus on privacy, and the only data that is shared with others is the data that your organization has explicitly chosen to share.

docs.title: Inability to Reproduce Cadres
docs.text:
Have you ever been in an organization where it all revolves around one really enthusiastic, hard-working person with whom all of the knowledge, the experience, and the skills lie with? KSBC has dealt with precisely that scenario, and it is a dire one that affects many organizations. In the best possibl case, that cadre will simply get burnt out and leave. In the worst case, that cadre becomes a charismatic leader like Mussolini and the organization degenerates into a cult.

The fundamental cause of this problem is that organizations do not have a formal mechanism or process for reproducing their cadres. An org runs on the labor power of its members, and if the burden of that labor power is concentrated on a select few, then the organization will be unable to function. No matter how well-intentioned the cadre might be, this state of afffairs will inevitably be anti-democratic.

DRUIDS cannot reproduce cadres. It is a piece of software, and it cannot do what a human being can do. However, DRUIDS can provide a framework for reproducing cadres by allowing you to: - Document the ideological growth of your membership - Track membership skills and experience - Ensure that the burden of labor power is fairly and equally distributed - Identify trends from data to give insight into recruitment efforts

docs.title: No Institutional Memory
docs.text:
Organizations often operate on "vibes" rather than systematic processes. Because the analysis is not centered around facts acquired through scientific inquiry and social investigations, the organization is unable to make rational decisions based on an objective understanding of the material conditions of the world. Therefore, decisions made at meetings never get implemented; action items lack owners and timelines; lessons learned are forgotten; and best practices aren't documented.

This creates a number of weaknesses in the organization. Firstly, it creates a breeding ground for the tendency of charismatic leadership because if there is no institutional memory, then everything falls on the shoulders of one guy. And if one guy has all of the information? All of the passwords, the experience, the knowledge, etc? That's just begging to create a Mussolini! Secondly, it's a direct contributor to burnout. All of the burdens and pressures falling on one persons shoulder is exhausting. Finally, it is the principal reason why orgs keep doing the same stuff over and over again but expecting different results.

DRUIDS cannot do everything in and of tiself, but one thing it can do and does very well, it to be your institutions memory. Let DRUIDS take th eburden off your shoulders. We will be your secure repository, your hard drive for bureaucracy.

docs.title: Security Errors
docs.text:
A common error made by many organizations is that they uphold what's known as "Security Theater". This is basically the error of "going through the motions" not because you understand them fully, but because that's just the way things have always been done and its whate veryone else is doing anyways. Security theater is about the illusion of feeling safe; it is an idealistic and bourgeois notion that centers around individual subjectivities. True security, however, is proletarian because it is a reproducible process based on scientific evidence and best practices. It is not a matter of feeling safe, but of being safe. Examples of security theater include:

  • Using an "encrypted" app without having actually investigated the esourcde code
  • Downloading the Signal app you use for sensitive communications from the Google Play Store.
  • Refusing to use an effective product because "a corporation made it" or because "it's fed technology" without realizing that those are actually the best indicators that it works!

Operational Security - or OPSEC - is another major mistake made by many orgs. By OPSEC we mean the process through which critical information is identified, and steps are taken to prevent adversarial forces (fascists, repressive police state) from accessing it. Closely related to OPSEC is the concept of Compartmentalization, which is the process of separating different types of information and work to limit exposure if security is breached.

Imagine you're in an organization, working on your personal computer on some sensitive political business. You download a secret document onto your personal computer. There's no separation! This is horribl esecurity practice. DRUIDS however, makes it quite litearlly impossible because the classifications of security levels - IE compartmentalization - is enforced technologically through the git repositories and branch structures. Assuming that permissions are assigned correctly, it is quite literally impossible to not have compartmentalization because it is baked into the structure of DRUIDS.1

Finally there is a complete lack of threat modeling. What little threat modeling exists, boils down to the vibes and feelings of individual members in the group. While we understand that sometimes peoples intuitions are correct, and often times the correct ones are formed through unfortunate experiences, it is equally true that just as often - if not moreso - that someones perceptions or intutions are wrong. The methods are not reproducible, and the results aren't verifiable. What organizations need especially in this era of ascendant and revanchist fascism is a systematic and reproducible process for identifying threats and taking steps to mitigate them. Security is best when it's proactive, not reactive. And DRUIDS, through its documentation system, can help you do just that.

Think of this real scenario2 that occurs all too often: some man is a known predator, and after he assaults someone in an org, he is evicted. But he simply moves to another one and does the same thing all over again because nobody documents anything, nobody keeps files or records, and therefore nobody can be said to have any sort of memory. This is a problem because it is a clear case of a failure to identify and mitigate threats. But what if you were using a system that made it super easy to document, track, and identify threats? THen not only could you prevent this all-too-common scenario from occuring, but you can furthermore share that information with other organizations to keep the community safe. Wouldn't that be great? Well it's possible with DRUIDS.

docs.title: Scatterbrained Reports
docs.text:
Have you ever had well-intentioned and eager members attend some sort of demonstration or event, but then when they back, they can't remember anything for the life of them? That's probably because they didn't document anything! And even if they did document something, then there's still the issue of dissemination. Where do comrades send their reports to and know that they will be secure and safe, their information protected? How do comrades know what kind of information is worth recording, and what is irrelveant or not useful?

DRUIDS is a perfect solution to these problems. Our security protocols are designed to keep things safe with hardware-based encryption, as well as the other security protocols discussed above. You can archive your data knowing it will be safe, and WILL NOT be seen by anybody unless you choose to share it with them proactively. That includes us as well! KSBC doesn't retain any ownership of your data, we don't receieve anything unless you want to share with us. DRUIDS also has a number of useful templates for reports, which completely solves the issue of how to report on events.

docs.title: "If It's On Your Phone, It Sucks"
docs.text:
Signal Problems:

  • No searchable archive
  • Conversations vanish in the scroll
  • One seized phone = exposed network
  • Can't onboard new members with history

Discord Problems:

  • They literally hand metadata to feds
  • Attachment URLs are public forever
  • Server raids expose everything
  • Pay-to-play for basic features

Google Docs Problems:

  • Google reads everything (and tells the feds)
  • "Who has edit access?" chaos
  • Version history is a joke
  • Scattered across personal accounts

docs.title: What Each Tool Is Actually Good For
docs.text:
Use Google Docs when:

  • You're writing public flyers
  • You need real-time collaboration on non-sensitive content
  • You don't care about long-term organization

Use Signal when:

  • You need quick, secure chats
  • Coordinating immediate actions
  • Information is ephemeral by design

Use Discord when:

  • Public community building
  • Nothing is sensitive
  • You need voice/video calls

Use DRUIDS when:

  • Building organizational memory
  • Managing sensitive + public information
  • Democratic decision-making matters
  • You're tired of the "one person has all passwords" problem

docs.title: The Bottom Line
docs.text:
DRUIDS isn't trying to replace every tool. It's solving specific problems:

  1. The Password Keeper Crisis - No more single point of failure
  2. The Raid Vulnerability - L2 isolation protects sensitive planning
  3. The Memory Hole - Decisions and history preserved forever
  4. The Onboarding Nightmare - New members can actually find things

If these aren't your problems, keep using what works. But if you've felt the pain of:

  • Lost meeting notes
  • Burned out secretaries
  • Security scares
  • Organizational amnesia

Then DRUIDS is built for you.
